content:
er 19, 2014
												To be bluntly honest, Champions Online could have really gone the mile for the Heroes/Villians genre of MMORPGs.  At the beginning, they had so much to offer; wardrobe customization, crafting for the crafters out there, missions that were really fun and entertaining, as well as some pretty heroic ideas for your arch nemesis.  Unfortunately, their hay day is, by far, over.  Now, it is a money sink, with their only additions being given to their cash shops.  Missions no longer roll out, most of their codebase is defective (arch-nemesis code is beyond repair, as has been stated by the developer's public relations division), and that's only the tip of the ice berg.  They started adding flying machines (like a mount) into the game where flight-based travel powers already exist.  The fun of hunting down villians has long-since been buried, replaced by an insta-que (or sometimes not instant at all), in which you wait for a team of other players to activate.  This places you in a variety of instances.  The same ones, over and over and over again.  The repetitious missions never change, save for the holiday events.  When Perfect World bought the developing company, they married their money-in-hand with the game.  This has meant that new powers are gone and done.  The broken skills are not being fixed (ask someone about the ice-based powers, the arcane based powers, or even the electric based powers), and the new things rolling into the game are meant to be purchased.  This goes for both the paying 15.00 a month customer, as well as the "free-for-all" customer. The original draw to this game for many was the PvP scenarios.  I played from original opening date, if anyone remembers Mother Night, Mother Dusk, and Madame Mirage (just to name a few), and the zombie scenario was always a huge hit for most of the players.  However, that is no longer the case.  To ensure I was giving an accurate and detailed synopsis of the condition in which the game now rests in, I signed in and queued for the PvP scenarios.  All of them.  On both freeform characters and the pre-builts.  2.5 hours later, the queue was still going.  I asked around in-game what was the cause of such a long wait, and I was told there was some sort of bug in the PvP system, as well as a lack of attraction to the the PvP system, that has caused it to go the way of the Dodo; right into extinction.  I asked how long this had been going on, and I was told it had been that way for about two years now.In conclusion, this game is going the same way as City of Heroes, only with a more drawn-out death that's not only painful to, but also just damned out-right depressing.

29, 2015
												City of Heroes was and still is my favorite MMOs of all time. CoH died a much to early death, leaving this MMO in its place.Champions Online is a very good MMO, with some problems. But nothing to keep you from playing. The gameplay itself doesnt bring anything *too* new to the table but it isnt your run of the mill, stand and shoot spells at each other MMO. It has a interesting combat system. You have a power that constantly building your energy (or mana for those fantasy mmo players) which you can then turn around and spend that energy on more powerful attacks. The Alerts (or dungeons) are nice and action packed. The missions can be very dull and stale sometimes, but that goes with any grind. The Nemesis system is a nice addition in which you can create your own archnemesis to fight. Problem is that the nemesis system leaves much to be desired. The character creator is fantastic and you could spend hours perfecting the look of your hero.The FTP model isnt the worst, but once you experience a freeform hero and the subscription privilages. You wont ever want to go free to play (or silver as they call it) again.I would suggest subbing to this MMO, but give it a try before hand.

content:
er 10, 2014
												Champions Online is a superhero MMO RPG game, that became Free2Play few years ago and is a spiritual successor of City of Heroes.You will have to make Perfect World account to play this game. The game isn't exactly at the peak of activity, but is still being updated with small events and new shop stuff. Community is also there, even if some zones are almost completely empty.Now, as far as gameplay itself goes it's a standart MMO RPG. Well, Superhero theme sure helps to set it aside from usual fantasy trash though. Colorful world and characters, as well as occasional nice action music. And that they got some more sense of gameplay, by having world that doesn't take few hours to travel though, while still giving it nice details. All characters having travel power helps. Gameplay also feels faster and arcadeys, but it's still same old target-based thing you seen before. The main gimmick is that in order to get "mana" (called "energy") you just have to keep using your most basic power on target. There is also Players vs Players duel mechanic, but it's just "abuse the week's most broken powers combinations".Now, the game is Free 2 Play. And yep, those who pay get gameplay stuff as well. Like, costumes, classes, small boosts. You can farm special "questionite" recources to trade those for in-game shop money, but it takes ages. You also can be a monthly sub, getting all the stuff by default. None the less, what you really should be looking forward are costume pieces and Freeform class. Because the strong point of this MMO is a customization!Freeform can be said is "the way that game is supposed to be played", as it allows you to pick absolutely any powers available in the game! Water, Thunder, Kung-fu, Dual Pistols, whatever. Sure thing having such broad selection bring problem where are some combinations are clearly more superior than others, as balancing so many powers would be near impossible. Sadly, F2Players only have access from beggining only to Archetypes (read: classes with pre-set powers.) and only to few of them.And biggest feature this MMO has: One of the best characters costume customizations around. It really is what keeps half of those players, who still play Champions, around, along with RolePlaying. It allows players to do wide arrange of things. Don't thing of thousands slides of "how thick is that eyebrow" or "wanna make that single muscle wide". Well, it does have some of such slider. But main focus will be on changing costume pieces of various body parts around, whetever it's belt, cape, head or wings. And there is many of costume pieces to choose from. You can make superhero of your dreams. Actually, what you can do and what many do, is to make a character who doesn't even look like your generic superhero, whetever it's some robot-zombie-pirate, anthro of your choice or, well, troll character that brings acid to your eyes. Though, I wouldn't say that it looks smooth, all non-human heads aren't animated, for example. Clipping is also the thing, but what you would expect from something what has this many choices.So yes, customization and costume creation is really something what outdoes any MMO and most of other video games, and you are most likely to learn what is "RolePlaying" from this MMO, which is quite common there thanks to features I just told you about. Thus game has great social-part value to it, while having slightly above-average for MMO gameplay part (and below-average compared to non-MMO games).Unless you don't care of such stuff.Or want sandbox.Or just sane videogamer.Still spent more time with it than I really should have.

content:
y 5
												I feel as though all of the negative reviews on this game were made by impatient, greedy people. The game has a fair amount of free content, and doesn't require you to purchase ANTYHING. It's free, as stated.Pros :- There is nothing stopping a silver player(A player without a subscription) from achieving the highest level, making a unique character, or enjoying the relatively small, mostly helpful community.- There are more than enough pre-unlocked costume pieces for you to customize to your hearts content. Ever wondered what Joker would look like dressed as Supes? Go for it. Got a niche for drawing weird hodgepodges of random !@#$ that concern your friends and family? Bring it to life here. Are you dying to make a Batman who altered his attire to more resemble some sort of bat/fox hybrid? Then you're already a fanboy! And lastly, do you like to imagine yourself as an anthropomorphic horse? Please don't.- The missions are varied, and the game is FILLED with constant references to random pop culture and movies. But fear not, Ron Mahogany doesn't have any issues with the pleats in his pants.- If you are not challenged in the monetary region, you can subscribe and go gold for only $15 dollars a month, with the option a lifetime sub for a one-off payment. You get more benefits, granted, but nothing which makes you any better PvP-wise, so there is no 'Pay-to-win'. You get access to free monthly premium currency, exclusive clothing options, freeform character slots, among other things. Freeform simply allows you to mix different powers between powersets. This doesn't necessarily mean you're more powerful when you do this, as the standard archetypes have their own advantages.- Aside from the given trolls that can be found in any game, the community is eager to help, with some recieving the occasional free gear, buffs and in-game currency to assist with getting started. I've done it multiple times myself.- There are many pros pertaining to this game, but I'm getting quite tired of writing this review, so I'm going to ramble more off, in no particular order of preference. Lore, social instances, numerous powers, powersets, and travel powers, content continuiously added, every time you reach level 40 on a character, you get another character slot, blah blah blah, this that and the other.Cons :- This goes for pretty much any MMO, but, grinding. It'll take some blood, sweat and tears to get your hands on the best gear in the game. Oh, and time.- Its been out a while. Eight years. How much longer can this game last? Probably a lot longer if you'd just download it and fall in love already.- Dwindling community besides its many faithful regulars.- Anthropomorphic lions, tigers and bears, oh my!------------------------------------------------------TL/DR : Get it. It's free. And awesome.

												To be honest.I started playing this game, three years ago. And throughout it all, I always wondered, 'would this be beneficial if i chose this' and blah blah blah. The main atmosphere in this game has changed drastically over the years, and I have invested most of my time in the roleplaying component of this game. This game, has changed drastically in that atmosphere over the years, and it used to be quite literally, an ERP (Erotic Roleplay) hub. And the large amount of dark characters for those purposes existed and some still do exist. You have to take into account that people get tired of the same repetetive chat and uncreative ways that can go. This game's RP atmosphere is definitely still darker than hell, and sure; there are still demon lesbians galore, but people have changed from these jerkbags who were obsessed with this stuff.People may insult me or charge at me for saying that but it is, or was true. I do however have quite a few good things to say about it.The character creation, to simply put it; is quite amazing. It is very very expansive and largely appealing to people who like creating characters, you can definitely give the impression of having strange ears by changing your character's head proportions as well as actually slotting an item in the side slot to cover it; and that's just an example. I have changed as well, but people here can be very helpful, though you should still be very careful of who you become friends with.

content:
er 6, 2013
												First off, this is an F2P, not a pay to win although some people will whine that it is. A lot of what you see in the store can be earned in the game free, but you have to work for it (ah there's the rub).On the pros side this game is great for people who love old comic books, and very very bad puns. The character cusomisation is extremely versitile (the more unlocks you have of course the more you have access to). Keep in mind though these are patterned after classic comic book looks and not realisim.If you like working on achivements you're going to be busy for a long long time.On the cons side the level cap is a bit restrictive, Doing the same quests over and over with different characters can get boring at times. Global chat can cause your brain to try and shut down (though how many global chats don't?)As a life member ($300 one time payment) you do get permentant gold status, a lot of unlocks, freeform characters (pick your powers as opposed to power sets) and new character slots everytime a character hits level 40 (as far as I've seen there seems to be no limit to the number of characters you can have), Much better than the pay by the month for gold then lose your status when you don't play for a while. Either that or stick to free (silver), do NOT try to go gold then derank to silver, you can never go gold again!!For me this is a fun game to play for a while, play other things, then come back to.

number of helpful: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
r 11, 2015
												1500+ hours player.The Good:- This might just be the best Character Creator ever in a video game, period. Just browsing the costume section of the official forums reveals just how in depth you can make a character. At the very least, this is on par with CoH. Which is to say it's incredible. Too bad the game around it is rather half-♥♥♥♥♥.- The Freeform system is awesome. Too bad if Silver (F2P) players want to use it, you have to drop 50 whole bucks. The Bad:- The game dosen't take its self seriously in the slightest, and (on the whole) the playerbase dosen't either.  For every awesome, original player who actually creates superheroes, there's always going to be 'Themeless' characters. Everything from a outragerous, over the top, aura covered mess, or someone who colours tights to give the illusion of being naked, or someone who copies Marvel/DC creations (There's an notoriously well-known supergroup who is entirely dedicated to this). It's all there.- The Alert System was a terrible idea. They're instanced content that can be completed in about 2 minutes. Smash, Grab, and Burst alerts give out XP, Resources, and Mods respectevly. Grab alerts aren't that bad, but the mods given out by Burst alerts are almost always useless. Smash alerts are the worst offender here, because they render the entire questing process completely irrelevant. You can aquire a reasonably large amount of XP in a very short amount of time. You can reach the level cap without even leaving the starting area. Sure, there's perks (the 713 achievments) to be had in the questing process, but perk points are like gamerscore, complely useless. They don't do anything. - Little to no Endgame. There's raids, but they BADLY NEED an revamp. There's only about 2-3 that the community are willing to do. - Immersion in non-existant. Remember what I said about 'Themeless characters'? They are everywhere. This extends to actual builds, Where they have summoning demons, celestial powers, calling in an airstike, a massive force of kinetic energy, mind control, and dual pistols all on the same character. They have the appearance of a hyper-anime little girl who never looses a slither of health and roflstomps everything. This is like the Iron-Skin spamming Rhino Primes in Warframe, but ten-times worse. Just try to get immersed here. I dare you.- Zone chat is a huge cancer. Disable it immedietly. You will not regret it. Champions can be enjoyable if you're willing to overlook the player who don't know they're playing a *SUPERHERO* MMO. You can share resources and gear between your characters, and there's no armor repair system, which I see as completly pointless and meaningless. Development has turned to an almost standstill, but both it and developer communication has started up again, and quite frequently.You might find a new virtual home here, just be prepared be disapointed in some (more that others) areas.

content:

												Although I do recommend this game, it does have its issues.  Pros: Fun Superhero MMOGreat travel powers/combat powersFun, immersive experience (for a while)Instant matchmaking alerts with supervillainsCons: Lack of communityNot as good as City of Heroes/VillainsNot many places to go end gameStarts to become dull around end gameWhile it starts off fun, the game does fall off about you've maxed out and begin grinding for end game gear.  I played City of Heroes from release to end, and as much as I miss the superhero MMO genre, this is basically just a filler until City of Titans is released.  I remember when Champions Online originally came out, I purchased it, but wasn't impressed at all.  Over the years, they've turned it into a much better game, but it still lacks.

r 30, 2016
												I have been playing Champions Online since it went free to play in 2011.  I have NOT paid real money for anything on my 4 accounts.  Currently, i only have 11 avatars, one of each free archetype, highest level 22.  Recently, added 4 freeform slots and a paid archetype for FREE.    I am an ex City of Heroes player, since COH died, i play Champions Online, when i need a superhero fix.   Champions Online is a free-to-play superhero-themed MMORPG by former City of Heroes developer Cryptic Studios based on the Champions ( Paper and Pencil game ) license.  Now owned by PWI, each PWI account give you access to every PWI game. The game's rules and setting are loosely based on the HERO System ruleset and has it's own universe. The graphics are like how American comic books look like.Your controls are limited to a few skill buttons.  The level cap is 40.  You can make 2 characters per account as free2play. It has one server with many instances, has world chat and ok matchmaking system.If you are not willing to pay real money, you still can have some fun on Champions Online, you just have to be limited in your choice of archetypes.  The game has ore you can collect as reward for certain missions and can be sold in game for store points.  Has a good cosmetic customization system even for F2P players.  Game Store has plenty of stuff for you to buy.The quest content is free and maybe enough to reach level cap.  If you reach lvl 40, you get a free archetype to play with.  Big with Roleplayers now.  Currently, Not many people playing lower level heroes, or teaming up on quests.  Has Steam Achievements.  Has crafting and gear to improve your character.  It is an good old superhero MMORPG.  I don't suggest you put any real money into it, till you give it a good try.for more info:

												I've only started this game when it first went F2P at the beginning of this year (before it came to Steam), and I have to admit that I’m always a little wary of trying out MMOs. They are addicting and consume much more of my time than I would like to admit. The greatest thing about ‘Champions’ is the amount of customization that you can do for your character. Obviously, there are the powers, but the selection of choosing how your character looks like is phenomenal. I’ve never seen such a system that lets you adjust so many aspects of your hero. It’s worth a try, even if it’s just because you like to design and tweak your avatars down to the very last detail. It’s a great superhero MMO and I got quite a bit of fun out of it. The art style is quite unique and it really does have that comic book feel. I would definitely play more if I had more free time.

content:
er 30, 2013
												I've played Champions Online since it first came out. Having come from the grindfest and overall nightmare that was City of Heroes I feel that Champions Onilne was a great way to do the super hero genre as an MMO.The simple fact that you can build a hero the way you want from the ground up, start to finish, is nothing short of amazing. The powers and costume combinations that you can build allow you to recreate almost any hero that has existed in comic books to date, or create your own version of what you think a hero is.The only downsides to this game are the lack of an ability to play anything other than a hero, the generic power selections, and the feel of the game. I like playing a hero in a super hero game...I mean that's the whole point, but it gets boring after a while to always be the good guy especially when you have powers that let you animate the dead or poison people or set people on fire. The power selections that are available to choose from scream for a villain side of the game. Yes you can make an "anti-hero" but he's still doing the same heroic deeds and stopping the same bad guys that every other hero is. There isn't any depth to the game in that respect. It's "Help! Someone stole/robbed/broke-into/kidnapped/is about destroy, this person/place/thing! Please stop them!"Rinse and repeat.The powers in the game are great for what they are. Each style has mutliple variations on how that power should function, but they are all still very generic and aside from some minor color changes you can make, you're still not going to see powers like you want them to be. They will be mere facades, posing as a cosmic blast, but being a kinetic blast of force in actuality.The combat in the game is good, but it's not very engaging. I don't feel like the hero so much as a person controlling the hero. It's a very "stand back and watch me blast this guy" type of gameplay, even for the melee archetypes. Just bland.Overall it's a very solid game even after Perfect World took over it's come out with some nifty little enhancements to make the game a little better than it was. The worst part of the game however is the C-Store and the purchases that can be made within. I highly suggest that if you intend to purchase anything from the store, you don't purchase the cosmic keys or participate in the lockbox sceme at all. If you intend to spend that kind of money on the game, then purchase the lifetime subscription instead and reap it's rewards, but stay away from the keys and lockboxes.

Who's idea was this again?- Far to cheesy. Far far far FAR to cheesy. The game makes it painfully obvious it was aimed specifically towards kids.Overall. The game excells in half of what it needs to excell at while falling near flat in the other. If your gonna get any real enjoyment or entertainment from this game I highly reccomend playing it with friends or generally not taking it seriously altogether. This is NOT a game you can take seriously either. Trust me. I tried.

content:
16, 2016
												Beyond the hours I've logged here, I've been playing the game since it came out and I've played a lot of it through PWE's "Arc".I bought Champions Online on launch several years ago; it was a completely different game than what it is now. It was a true-blooded cRPG, which relied on you making all the right choices when leveling and choosing your gear. You could be any kind of super-hero with any kind of power available, but at the price of truly balanced classes. Since the game turned f2p and PWE bought it, it has changed and not for the better. Progression is linear, unless you are subscribed and have "Freeform" slots. Everyone else picks an archetype (a great deal of them require money) and the game chooses the progression of the build for you. A lot of the leveling content is boring and mindelessly repetitive. Endgame content may as well be non-existent and, as of the time of writing this, hasn't seen any significant updates in years.But there is still value in playing and here's why: if you're here for gameplay, get out. Find something else to play, or something else to do with your time entirely. LARPing will yield better results.But if you're here to satisfy your super-hero fantasies, come right in. Customization is insane, a lot of the costume pieces require money, but they're sensibly-priced (as long as you understand that's mainly what you'll be spending money on, in this game) and it's a fairly largely populated game, despite the lack of content.My advice, as someone who's had problems with this game in every form it has ever been in, is this: make your hero. Customize them to your heart's content. Have a look at the store for aesthetics or even powers and services. Play as much of the leveling content as you can stomach. Join a Roleplay Supergroup. Get in character. Take your buddies to battle with you. Pretend the random gang-member NPC on that one snow-covered hill in Canada is the guy that bullied your hero when they were in high-school. Shoot the NPC with your laser-eyes. Explain your tragic origin to your fellow heroes over the bully's smoking body. Then you can safely say you "get" what this game is all about.

												Deceptively fun for an MMO. At least up to level 11, it's all soloable and mostly free of spending an hour grinding for dire weasel nostrils; the closest is some gang control which is either short or in interesting terrain (it sets off the urge to explore and try to find all the highest places to base-jump from, activating your flight/teleport superpower just before you hit). It feels more like a single-player real-time combat RPG that just has other people smashing stuff in the background except for occasionally forming ad-hoc teams on open missions or clearing the streets, which is a great kind of multiplayer for something with the random public. And has one of the neatest tutorial campaigns I've seen.Quite a bit of wiggle-room in character creation too, as long as you don't mind the bodytypes being variations of barrel-chested men and pencil-waisted women, with optional animal heads. It's got its golden age of comics theme and it's pretty much sticking to it.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2011
												Excellent game for fans of comic books and/or performing various types of violence upon sytlized bad guys. Plus it's free. Plus you can throw trucks at people. Plus you can set them on fire after you throw the truck at them. Plus you can wear tights while doing so.Adding onto this with some more detail. Let's look at this from the three core areas I see in the game: Design, Customization, and Story. I'll also talk at the end about grinding.DesignThe game is rendered in a cel-shaded aesthetic. The creators did a great job making almost every part of the game look like a classic comic book. There are some sets that give more of a 90s Saturday Morning Cartoon style, but they still fit into the aesthetic. Moreover, all the locations are done in a similar style and the game applies different filters and effects on top to give different moods depending on the story. Horrific dream sequences are made with stark black and white high contrast filters. Mysterious sewers are given more of a squishy feel with low contrast high blur filters.CustomizationAs everyone else will tell you, the game boasts an immense degree of customization. You will rarely, if ever, see two players who look the same. Some will fall into standard tropes, but they will always be different and that is thanks to the powerful customization options. As you might expect, you can put on different costume pieces, but you also have control over your hero's body shape. Make your hero bigger, smaller, longer, shorter, thicker, or thinner both overall and for individual body parts. Maybe your hero got his powers in a candy factory and he now has freakishly long limbs. Maybe your hero is the reincarnation of a T-Rex and has wee little arms. In addition, you can customize how your hero stands. Perhaps they act heroic and strike a pose every chance they get or maybe they stand like a normal person. Add onto this the fact that all heros, even the ones immediately available to new players, can choose at least some of their powers. While subscribers can customize pretty much all their powers, free players still have a great degree of flexibility in how they build their hero's powerset. Maybe you choose more AoE or more single target damage. Maybe you boost your threat generator so you can be a better tank. From there, there are specializations that give your powers special boosts. A bit of bonus crits here, a bit of stacking DoT over there, some vampiric aura under there, etc.StoryThe story is a complex subject. On the one hand, much of it is very much steeped in comic book tropes. You have your standard slum gangs, your evil weapons manufacturers, your mystic snake lovers, your twisted horrors from an eldrich plane, your alternate universe where everything is the opposite, the evil robots, the going back in time to stop the thing, etc. On the other hand, this is part of the charm. It is very self-referential and often self-aware (find the "Defender Fanboy" for some good laughs). It never claims to be bringing you the next great Shakespeare but, for me, the fact that you are fighting the big bad evil without much complexity in the plot is pretty much part of the genre the creators based the game off of.GrindingOne final note on grinding. The game gets somewhat grindy at the level cap. Personally, I don't think this is unique to this MMO. At some point, the developers put in repeatable content that you need to do often to get large rewards. I think the game does a good job with this. Most importantly, there are lots of potential grinds for you to do, so for me it never got boring. Let's go over them. SPOILERS possibly beyond.1. UNITYAt the end, you are granted access to a group which sends you on daily quests. These quests are semi-random and fit with the rest of the game's quests which usually boil down to "find bad guy, kick bad guy till he falls over". Once you do the daily quests, you can do a special larger one at the end that is usually a little more special although it still pulls from a finite bank of quests so you will sometimes do the same mission again the next day or something. In addition, there is a repeatable quest to go to an arena and fight your way to an important villain and defeat him. This and another level-cap boss are often considered "beating" the game and people usually play these multiple times to get rare rewards like costume unlocks.2. Adventure Packs/Comic SeriesThese missions are larger stories outside the main areas you get access to. They give out lots of different rewards like costume unlocks, action figures, as well as Questionite, which is the currency used to buy special items and/or convert into the paid currency.3. AlertsThese are randomized encounters that you can queue up for. The game partners you with 4 other heroes who have to take down the villain. The alerts come in three flavors based on the bonus they provide: XP, Resources (gold), and Mod (upgrades for gear). Players often go through at least three each day because of a quest that grants Questionite upon completion and for the bonuses they provide. XP is great for characters either under the level cap or for those heroes who have died a lot and lost their stars (which make you a little weaker). Resources is good for those who need more Resources (measured in Global/National/Local influence, which is a nice touch) either to buy gear off the auction house or pay for things like costume changesIn all, the grinding to me feels a lot like how I felt in Minecraft: There are so many things to actually do, that I never get sick of one of them.

												Well, for starters I've been playing Champions Online since I was able to play for the week for Life Time Member's could play. During that week I managed to get a Electrical Character to lv 33 till I got distracted by other games. This game is a comic style game imo, It has a comicy feeling for me. number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
5, 2014
												I've played Champions Online off-and-on for about 3 years now. The game can be fun if you make it fun. The end-game content exists, but its not really something you strive to do. The player community has its up and down moments like any MMO does. The game itself is comic book-ish, as can be guessed by the screenshots and whatnot. I often use CO as my "Between MMOs" MMO. When I quit WoW and waited on TOR, I used CO as a buffer for a couple of months to kill time and whatnot. I'm doing the same thing now as I have quit TOR and waiting on ESO to drop.The game has great customizations even on the free-to-play side. You can get lost in the customization alone for hours. Be careful if you decide to make a female character however. I can't tell you how many times I get whispers for ERP from folks I don't know, who happen to see my character (Shes in full arrmor....whadaheck how can they know if they wana plow her or not?!).If you're just a casual gamer/MMO player and you never really strive to get to endgame stuff and raid, then this game might be worth your time; after all, its free. RP exists, but often ends with people trying to poke holes in your tights so they can stick things into said holes. PvP is alright, nothing super special in my opinion.HOWEVERThe game is TOTALLY Pay to Win. The FTP skills and whatnot...you're gonna be a wimp compaired to anyone who pays for the game. You could be expecting this, but the scale difference between FTP and Sub is amazing. Personally, I found that th egame's FTP status made me feel more like quitting several times than subbing for stuff.There are several major bugs that I have seen sit and stay in game over the 3 years that I've been on and off this game. OVERALLThis game would be decent if they'd fix their bugs, and work so that subbing seems like something to be enjoyed, not "the only way to be any good at the game". A serious MMO player should overlook this, but a child, or a casual player, or someone totally new to MMOs might enjoy this. Comming from a serious MMO'er though, I'd give this a 2 out of 10.

content:
26, 2012
												Remember Mario Paint back on the Super Nintendo? You know, a game that let you make stuff? I think the only thing it was really lacking is the ability to take what you make and go live with it.That's where Champions Online comes in, and probably why my very first day with this game I spent EIGHT HOURS in character creation and didn't get to the actual GAME. Sometimes the options are overwhelming but there was always massive appeal for me in taking character ideas I've had for years and fleshing them out as playable game characters. And the icing on the cake? That game is online so I can show off to others.Having gushed a bit there, I am admittedly not a major MMO fan. So many I've played before kinda ruined it for me. Champions brought me back in with its more action-oriented gameplay. It feels more immersive to actually input commands and either have them executed right then or begin to charge up. It all just feels very fast paced and the first time through, it's a blast.Granted, after playing this game for years, it's worn a little thin, but I was mostly a solo player. Going back through with friends is always fun, and sometimes just hanging out is awesome. Probably the closest thing I can think of that I compare this to is Second Life, which isn't as engaging or accessible (in my opinion, at least).It's nice to see so many options available so players can be damn-near anything they want. A little more VARIETY in those options would rock, too. (Seriously, why FIVE wolf heads?) Overall, Cryptic's done a hell of a job with this, even if I'm not religiously tethered to the game. Champs is nice to return to in my downtime from other games, work, or life in general.

												(I've been playing the game on Arc so I have a lot of unlisted hours)TL;DR: Don't bother playing if you don't RP, and don't bother PVPing if you're not gold. If you meet those requirements it's endless fun.Pros: Nearly Unlimited CustomizationFun PVPCons:Both of the listed Pros only really comes to Gold members (meaning you need to pay) its $15 a month or $300 for lifetime (and it pays itself off rather quickly)A lot of the updates are pay, the game has gotten rather greedy and the company has a habit of caring and focusing on one game, making a new one and abandoning it.A little buggy and fustrating, and being SIlver SUCKS, the game isn't worth it if you're Free-to-Play.To get more in detail...if you're subcribed the game it's really fun and has a lot of replay ability (in my opinion). But it's only the Role-play. Half the fun is making a new character, making a good theme build for them (you get to test them out in the PTS if you're gold) And every once in awhile they'll give out 2x XP which will level them up quickly.Main problem with the game though is Cryptic/Perfect Worlds don't really care for the game, and it's probably the last on their priority list with Star Trek Online and Neverwinter. And the only hope of the game actually taking off and getting new content is if more people played it!Now that's a lot of bad things but nevertheless, it's the only game I've played that has such a large role-play community and such great customization that allows you to create really cool characters!That's pretty much the end of my first serious review. Keep it good!

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
4, 2014
												This game stagnated. Went stale. Really stale. Cryptic sold it to PWE, and it started churning out vehicles and a bunch of reskins for the vehicles. It became lockbox mania. Every other kill, you'd get a lockbox. Then they stopped, pulled it together, and turned the game back in the right direction: more actual content, fewer lockboxes cluttering your inventory. The lockboxes are once again in your inventory, but they don't drop like nuts. The long-demanded purchasable free form slots are around now, at a hefty $50 but hey, we've paid more for smaller games. I should also mention, now including the adventure packs but not a few other things, the game is free. You can play through the whole thing from level 1 to 40. No experience penalties for being a free account or anything (I'm looking at YOU, SWTOR). The main drawback is that you HAVE to use an archetype, and only from a select list - you don't get to pick your own powers as you go without buying a freeform slot or paying the subscription. However, given the a large number of MMOs don't really let you pick your own powers from a very broad set, it should feel pretty normal. In fact, it's kind of nice not having to worry about all the choices, because the already large powers list has only gotten bigger over time. Start of playing for free, for sure, until you get a hang of the game. Old updates like the 10-man boss "Rampage" events have recently been re-done. The old teleportation glitch is still around, though. At the end of a teleport, you get slow fall for ten seconds. If you fly or teleport while slowfall is active, you will be dragged to the ground. Surely they can just make teleportation and flight powers cancel out slow fall when they're first cast... Anyways. Costumes. How badass you look will have nothing to do with your stats and will often have very little to do with special gear cluttering your important slots. There are some pieces of equipment that give you a special dark aura, or dark speed, stuff like that, but they don't take up your equipment slots. Costumes are 100% cosmetic with a quite wonderful selection even for free players. With a subscription, you get a bunch more costumes thrown in and a 500 Zen/month stipend you can go ahead and just buy those extra costumes with. And with the game's rather open lore (though it does exist), roleplay is hard to resist. ...just remember to bring a friend into the game with you. Leveling can start too feel a little too much like a grind around the 20th time you level through Westside. And yes, I've gone through Westside that many times. Also, if you play this, tell Poe Ghost hello. He's pretty scaley. And then tell the rest of the people Poe sent you.

ry 7, 2014
												Champions Online is now four'ish years old and the developers have worked tirelessly to improve game play, include new content and resolve the bugs which were abundant on the initial release. It's now free-to-play, they still offer lifetime memberships as well as monthly accounts for extra perks. Graphics are great and support DirectX 11 -- posted tweaks on Steam to make them even better. The game play is fast and action oriented, the new alert system puts you in the action instantly, the characters are customizable with character points in addition to powers, you can create your own nemesis which appears in the world. It's worth travelling back to Millennium City to see the improvements -- for free!

content:
19, 2016
												I will be blunt and say I don't recommend this game. The reasons are below, behind is just the TL;DR.PERSONAL EXPERIENCE: I started playing this game 3 years back, I'd played Guild Wars 2 and SWTOR at that time and found both to be lacking, for a time it filled the void left by City of Heroes when it shut down *Taken too soon.*Now note I said: For a time, after a while the problems started to pop up, what didn't help the issue was that it was run by PWE *Perfect World Entertainment* at that time and THAT is a massive example of Corporate Greed, they would ignore obvious needs for rebalancing or a reduction of damage for the sake of things you bought with RL Money, never added anything to change the Vapid gameplay and overall they did things that turned me off of it for a while.Then I returned a year later to a game run by PROPER Devs and I enjoyed it for a short time, even making a whole new character and playing him to 40, then a glitch basically made him unusable...The reason I kept coming back was the RP and that was mainly because a good number of its original community were people from City of Heroes *it was actually a huge draw for me* but the community wasn't enough to excuse the gameplay and its nature...Sure City of Heroes had repettitive gameplay but you could excuse it for two reasons: 1: it was made at the time this was popular and 2: the levels were FUN to play through so people didn't mind this and this was on top of the amazing community.This game on the other hand is repetitive and BORING...Not even the active bits of the combat could keep me riveted so I started just hamming it up in a sort of 'I REALLY don't care.' matter. And the age of Comics they went with was NOT well done as you have to balance it out proper with comedy in SMALL points, not all over the damn place, your enemy groups need to have MORE threat even under a silly exterior. Comparring the Hunter-Patriots with Malta is an unfair contest in Malta's Favor.The customization *While far more than DCUO...URGH that's a subject that needs tackling another day* pales in comparrison to City of Heroes, which would be 12 years old now if it were still around, because before it had its many updates, it still had WAY WAY WAY more customization in every aspect. After the updates you could make entire story arcs yourself using Archetect Entertainment and Change how your powers looked not just in color but in some cases how they ANIMATED!Grouping is almost BEYOND impossible even with a paragon of patience as it takes a while to get people to join you in something that actually REQUIRES people, the PvP could have been handled better *Stupid Queue system mixed with Bad Server Issues meant you could easily miss ALMOST THE ENTIREITY OF THE MATCH YOU QUEUED FOR* The big missions could have had specific people to talk to who wouldn't give you the mission if you didn't have a team of *Insert number of players here* the group limit is rather STUPIDLY low *Unsettlingly so* FINALLY None of the arcs *with the exception of the Victoria Bay Apocalypse arc* have any real investment or worthwhile payoff.In the end...I would say 'Play City of Heroes instead' but its gone *Damn you NCSoft* so instead I say this: Keep looking, maybe look up City of Titans or other projects in the similar vein of Spiritual Successors, they're looking good and if they rock when they come out and keep rocking, I'm pretty sure this game would DIE a very slow death.

I came back to find my account was hacked and all my characters and money was gone from both games. I was still able to login to the game and my arc account without issue. I submitted a ticket and subscribed to champions online to get started. No sooner did I pay for my subscription than my account was listed as banned and I was emailed for verification details. It has been 4 days since is sent the details and I havent been able to play either game. I recieved an email 3 days ago saying that my ticket has been escalated, but have heard nothing since then. I cannot believe the incredibly ♥♥♥♥♥♥ support and response time, but also that they would lock me out of my account after I subscribed. I highly doubt I would get reimbersed for this time even if I still wanted to play (which I dont at this point).To put this in perspective, I thought I had cancelled my 6-month autorenew for WoW and I noticed I was charged for another 6 months the other day. Less than 24 hours after submitting my ticket I had a full reimbursement without any additional fuss.

content:
8
												City of Heroes was a much better hero game. Loads of content, much greater hero variety, and developers that remained passionate about their work and the game itself from the day it went gold, and even after it was wrongfully shut down. The only thing I can think of that CO does better is with power selection, specifically free-form. Building a hero and seeing them come to fruition is very fun, but the content is so bare bones, and the community so bled dry from the monotony and lack of expansion, that this game is basically dead to the world.I, myself, enjoyed the action the game offers, but "Alert" instances are the status quo within the community and they get old pretty quickly. It's a shame, because with more funding and a fresh, skilled development team, this game could have seen its full potential, and the community would have thrived.

												Champions Online was the first MMO I played that derailed the World of Warcraft Juggernaut for me, and that's back when it was pay to play. Combat is dynamic, fast paced and a lot less about rotation and more about situation and play style. Obviously as F2P it has limitations. The gold subscription unlocks everything but a few costume bits, you even get a free token for one of the new hideouts. You can play through the game from start to endgame without paying anything and free is a reasonable price for that. Finally, there's an active Roleplaying community.Better then the critic score gives it credit for.

content:
ry 10, 2014
												Champions Online. To put it simply this game is limited to the users imagination. If you can think of an idea, let it flow and give it shape. Download this game. Don't even second guess yourself. If you want customization, crazy worlds. Things you thought impossible. Well. I'm telling you its all perfectly possible. Now then. Onto an actual review of this game.Once it went Free to Play, naturally i jumped at the oppertunity to play such a game, but i was disappointed and surpised on a number of areas. The first being the silver and gold platforms for playing. (Silver being the base model of F2P and Gold being a subscriber status of the game) If you want some neat features, extra perks. I highly recommend you buy Gold membership (Never been gold but i am ashamed to say i have pumped far too much money into this game.) For the small pricetag you pay your getting alot, this is including the "Freeform" character feature. (I'll touch on this later!)Not too mention the new aura system and dare I say it.. Vehicles. Ugh. (Not as good as they sound.. Keep reading for my opinion on these.)So before i continue i want to sidetrack with you with abit of history of the point of view from a Veteran Silver. Content has really, REALLY been lacking these past few months. With most of the attention shifting to "STO" (Star Trek Online) One of Cryptics other ventures before being brought out. So yeah. Theres been little to no quality control and content added to the game recently. Even old features such as missions from Adventure packs - (Buyable DLC expansion packs which were made free by Perfect World Entertainment) remain just undoable because of heavy bugs from the game. (Which probably won't ever get fixed..)Freeform your characters.Its exactly as it sounds. Want a fire character who can shoot electricity? You can do it. Want a sorcerer with a cheeky sidearm? Why not! How about a robot who has floating drones.. Or even Ice wolves as pets!? Do it already! Freeform is your golden ticket into the chocolate factory. Imagine, Create and have Fun! If you are subscribed to the membership system ingame you will automatically have access to this feature. Silvers can also buy access to this feature.. For the small sum of £50 or $50, in the respected countries. Soo yeah. Thankyou PWE for this but.. I think its best we wait for Half-price sales.Vehicles.Oh my gosh.. Just a waste of money. They might look cool but you will barely ever use them. Weapons do limited damage. If anything they are useable trophies. (Did i mention you can only use them outside?) Just save yourself some money. Say NO to vehicles!To put this bluntly. Most of these new features is to keep the playerbase for hanging on. The game is dying. I'm sorry but it is. I can recommend this, but it probably won't be around for the remainder of 2014.

content:
y 3, 2014
												Character and Power customization = 10/10Everything else = 5/10Overall rating = 7,5Shame that this game lacks in content after you've run through everything a couple of times (other than farming and collecting), because the character creator is amazing and very versatile, the best I've seen in any MMO. The power customization is excellent as well, given you pay for the subscription. The game is worth it just for its' ability to create exactly the character you want, down to the tiniest detail. At least it is to me.It's F2P, and you can essentially play a character from level 1 to 40 while paying nothing. But it does suffer from being a F2P game in the sense that there's a lot of fluff to buy, including some of the best items locked behind gamble-boxes, and most of the content coming out is quickly consumed. No new zones, no new long quest lines ending with epic villains, no major updates/bugfixes to outdated systems (PvP is dead and rewards useless, Nemesis content is bugged to hell and has been for years). It has gotten better with the new devs, but I wouldn't expect major updates or expansions in that direction any time soon. Since this game went FTP, if you take away the content relating to gamble-boxes, quickly consumed content(alerts and the like), becomes (toggle-ables where you become a different monster/character, most of them (only) useful if you're not a subscriber), and vehicles (essentially also becomes), you're left with costume items, new gear, and other collectibles, as well as some power updates, updates of a couple of systems and a few bug fixes. This might look like a lot written down, but compared to the fact that this game is over four years old, it isn't that impressive. Go to the website and look at the patch notes for this game and compare it to so many other games, it'll give you an idea of the pace this game is moving at.So once you get bored of sitting on your pile of shinies, there's not much to do but run a character through the same stuff all over again, blasting through Westside so many times you could point out every little pixel blindfolded. But having the power to create just the character you want, and thinking up your own story as you go along, somewhat makes up for running through the same content a million times. Luckily this won't be a problem until you've been playing the game for a while.If you have a good imagination, and you're not bothered by repetitive content, you'll have hours upon hours of fun. I certainly keep coming back.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
6, 2014
												(NOTICE! This game has many abilities and costume pieces you must BUY with their Real Money Currency, AKA, "0Zen" or have the super pricy Lifteme Membership to get access to. Even without those costume pieces, this game is still awesome, but just remember, You get what you pay for. And it's a F2P, or an Optional Subscription, or a Buy a lifetime of subscription) Even though it says I've only played a few hours, I've played this game since long before it was on steam, and it was awesome every, single step of the way.The first thing that was awesome? The Character Customization! I made a character that looks like Jack from ME2, a Karate Bird Man, A 4 ft. tall ninja, a rat called "Cheese Inc.", a giant Robot Raptor Mech with Orange Holographic Armor, and giant metal wings. Equipping armor doesn't change your character's appearance, so you never have to worry about being forced to wear the ugliest gloves on earth, or a skirt (hint hint, Blizzard Entertainment. HINT HINT!!!)The second thing? The Ability Customization! I have a character called "The Everything Man". He just looks like a normal dude with a really huge backpack. He then whips out dual pistols and shoots you 15 times, shoots a sonic arrow from his Hi-Tech Laser Bow, hits you with a fireball, summons a telekinetic sword and dices you up, then swings away on a rope. And it's a totally viable build. Also, you can change the color of your abilites, and you can even change where some come from (from a select list, not wherever you choose... so dont get any ideas...) You can shoot red colored ice shards from your chest, or green fire balls from your face, or even purple wind gusts out your fists Whatever you want.Third on the list we have... The Travel Powers! You can swing on a rope, you can teleport, you can fly (with a cape, with giant firey phoenix wings, whatever. Its up to you.), You can tunnel underground and pop up under your enemies, you can Superjump, You can zip around the world with Superspeed. You can float about on a giant hunk of rock, or spin about in a tornado. ANYTHING!!! And all of those were just off the top of my head! Also, there are probably 6 different forms of flight to choose from, so you'll probably have one you like.Fourth, Combat. Its fun and intuitive. At the same time (like, omg!). You can do what I did and just throw together something  crazy and it'll work, or you can really read into every ability and make a crazy build that causes all kinds of combos to happen  that heal you, buff you, etc. One thing that was a *SLIGHTLY* bad thing, was that enemies always fall facefirst when they die, unless you kill them with a knockback, wherein they will die face up, but it doesn't really matter that much.Last but not least, the community. I'll give an(other). There is a guild that throws a weekly Costume Contest and rewards the winners with the equivalent of 100 Gold, and they even have honorable mentions that get 50 Gold. Crazy huh!?  I know!!! And all of its in a F2P (NOTE!!! You get what you pay for, so some things will be locked off if you dont pay a subscription or get a Lifetime membership, which, last I saw, was really pricey.) But still, even the F2P version has quite a few different things you can do.Have Fun, and Download this game! Well, come on, do it! DOWNLOAD IT! SERIOUSLY!! DO IT NOW MON, DO IT NOW!!!

												This game WAS totally awesome. When I had to pay for it monthly.Greatest character editor ever. I think I spend as much time in the creator than in the game itself - witch was funny, full of wonderfull content. Great amount of cool skills you could combine as you wished to. Smooth combat system (yes it's a mana-skill-1-2-3-X system but it's fun and more action-styled than many others that came before and after).The movement powers were so... enjoyable (fyling is just boring... check out rocket-boot-jump or teleport :P).And the NEMESIS part is a little underused but creating your own arch-enemy (henchmen included!) was just to sweet.The free-to-play version just feels wrong - especially if you knew what else this game has(d) to offer... but then you have to pay for it...I returned after over a year of not having played to find all my former character locked. I was tempted to re-unlock some of my favorites (eternal love for Killerbunny) but then I saw I had to buy every costume part and every power I used... So it was : GoodbyeCreating a new - but stripped down character (content wise) was just... unsatisfying.IF you can afford to unlock free-character building (I'm not sure if this is even possible anymore) - most of the content (without you wont be able to level up smoothly) and at least a big chunk of costume partsTHEN enjoy a very sweet MMORPG witch has tons of cool stuffIF NOT: keep the **** away - this castrated "free" version is an insult to the original game

content:
ber 23, 2015
												I have some praises for this game but for those who are looking for a good f2p experience, this is almost definitely not your game.So I'm gonna make this clear here and now.You are probably not going to have much fun with this game unless you sink some money into it since its where most of the content lies. Champions Online is an MMO with a superhero theme to it if it was not obvious enough. I started playing this way back in the day probably as early as 2011 though I didn't really seriously pick it up until maybe around 2013. I played for a while and unlocked one of the 'gold' archtypes with real money. I played, made a character, tried to make a story and such out of it since the game seems to encourage you to do that with the nemesis system and all.But again most of fun doesn't really happen until you either unlock a freeform slot with money separately or you get a gold sub for the game which you can do on different terms like monthly and yearly from memory or you can do what I did and dig in for the lifetime sub that lasts until the game inevitably shuts down.Doing this allow you to access freeform slots which are basically slots in which you can customise every aspect of your character from primary and secondary main stats, powers and skill trees, This is where most of the fun can come into it since you can make the character how you want it instead of having to follow a set skill system but unfortunate it is behind a paywall.That said though from the last time I played it, the game is pretty dead, there are people around yes but maybe 4-500 tops on good days. The end content is kind of dull as well getting your usual dailies and such though there are special 'comic' missions that are basically mini campaigns separate from the main story. Rampages are where you will probably spend most of your time when you get to max level (which is 40 btw) cause it's where you need to farm the materials for the best equipment in the game. Drop rates are pretty bad so you are going to have to grind for quite a while to get anything to drop for you and even then you need like 6 of each item (add there are about 3-4 different rampage items) in order to make a full set of armour and if you have multiple characters, be ready for the long grind.The game is also microtransactions galore from costume sets to powers to 'lockboxes' which are boxes you need to open with keys that cost 100 Zen a piece which is the premium currency for the game in order to unlock special costumes and vehicles that only come from those lockboxes, or just wait until they turn up in the auction house for a pretty penny (ie stupidity expensive cause price gouging is popular with players in the game).However all of that I did ignore cause if there is one praise I have for thise game it's the pretty robust character creation system where you can select from a ton of different options (a lot are premium parts but once unlocked they are unlocked amongst all character and future ones on your account). You can be an undead superhero, a mad scientist, an Iron Man wannabe, or if you are the kind of person I am, you create a variety of anthropomorphic superheroes.Story is pretty bland in a lot of places and some of the voice acting/lip and body animations will leave you cringing as you meet characters that are pretty clear ripoffs of superheroes like Iron Man, The Flash and organisations like S.H.I.E.L.D.Do I recommend this game? If you have the cash you are willing to input into the game for a gold sub then maybe yes but this game has a lot of things that needs fixing before it's close to anything mainstream. However if you can look past that, you can really get lost in the character creation system, creating many different heroes with varying powers from fire to poison to demonic powers to kinetic force.

content:
1, 2014
												You know, this game has one defining charecteristic. Just one. But god dang it, that one thing was so huge that it made this game a joy to play for anyone with an ounce of imagination and creativity.Charecter customisation.I mean, you want to be a robotic samurai werewolf? thats doable.You want to be an alien necromancer that also has hairy hands? I've seen more then a few.You want to be a duke nukem knock off named retro-man? I've met that guy. Even acted like Duke.This game was narvana for a role player or... just anyone looking for a game with a bunch of crazy looking super heros. That is the only unique thing about it... but OOOOOH is it such a saveing grace.But guess what? People done goofed. Due to being flooded with new accounts, charecter creation has been slammed down on for new players, locking out a vast majority of options untill you've spent some time on the game.Now let me make it clear right here, I get it. I ♥♥♥♥ing get it. It's not good that all these new accounts have been made exclusivly to make more charecters for free. That's not good. It's robbing the company of money. I get it. It's a serious problem that needs to be adressed.(channles inner nostalgia critic)BUT GOD ♥♥♥♥ING DAMMIT. YOU DON'T HAMSTRING YOUR PRODUCT'S ONE SAVEING GRACE TO DO THAT. YOU DON'T CUT YOURSELF DOWN LIKE THAT FOR ANY SITUATION. THAT MAKES NO SEEEEEEENCE! *pant, pant*I understand that it's only temporary. I get that the lock clears up when you finnish the tutorial, but oh my god this was such a dumb move! The first 10 minuets of gameplay is when you need to hook your player. if you havent done that, there expectations will plummit and most will abandon the game altogether. Gameplay dosent start when you first enter the world eather, it starts the second you log in. that includes charecter generation.Again, I get it. This massive flooding of accounts to bypass the 2 charecter slot limmet is unacceptable. But there's better ways around this problem. Give players a chance to earn charecter slots. give them more then 2 to start out with. Find a better way! Please! Thats really my one issue here! If it wasent here, I would give this game all the praise in the world for being a ♥♥♥♥ing RPer's paradise!You know. this is the first negitive review I've ever made, and it's actualy on a game I have some fond memorys of. This is honestly very sad to me.I'll be fair though... If your willing to put in the time to slog through the first half hour of the game with an unispired charecter, this game can wind up being something really cool.

Product received for free
												This game allows for a very large variety character customization. While I've seen similar themes the character creation at even the silver/free level character creation is amazing! The graphics are in line with trying to keep you thinking its a comic book story. I am hard pressed to find a free to play game that allows you to play to max level (40) as your own hero. The game is rather heavy in the RP (roleplaying) community. This really gives you a break from the grind to give your character a deep back story. The game offers hideouts and you can buy more then one. As well as costumes for being a hero/hiding among the populace/ going to the club. Not satisfied flying around the city at lvl 6? Then you can work toward buying a specialized vehicle. There are also different types of helpers you can purchase (pets) that actually help you in combat. I recommed this game for anyone looking to immerse yourself into a comic book MMORPG.

content:
4
												This game suffers some of the same problems the Deadpool game of 2013 had: Too much mindless combat, too many supporting heroes, too little effort in the story. Unfortunately it doesn't come with a questionably-charismatic hero to redeem itself.Aside from that, as an MMO its combat system is in a few ways innovative, yet in many more ways backwards. Perhaps my opinion is wrong because I just never got a properly structured group, but in queued instances in particular I found that the groups I got into would expect to wipe 5 or so times before completing the instance, something I'd realized would be due to the un-tankiness of the tanks.It's been so long that I can't recall how its old competitor, CoX, handled the tank and healer, but I do recall that its combat system was far better structured and its instances were far easier to tank, in particular.CO flopped on its release, I'd attribute it to a lack of game more than it being a niche market. They've since gone steadily downhill, BUT during the couple of weeks I'd tried the game again I realized the devs have been very earnestly attempting to patch things up as of late, with weekly patches and a very active test server even. Unfortunately it feels to me like they'd have to do a FFXIV and remake the game.

content:
2012
												It all began and ended with the Lockboxes.I've sunk tons of money and time into this game, much, much more than Steam has recorded (Roughly 4 years).The game was pretty buggy when I started and it's gotten much, much worse over the years, it runs like ♥♥♥♥, power mechanics a either broken to not work or broken to work too well.PvP is dead, PvE is dead, there's no meaningful content released and no one playing the structured PvP modes. A new dev team took over after Perfect World took the previous team away to work on NW (also ♥♥♥♥) and there was hope for the future.But they are absolutely rubbish, it's taken them an incredible amount of time to develop what content they actually have and they just recently, at the time of writing, massively increased the price of most of the costume packs.The (public) RP scene is the worst in any game, It was never amazing quality but it was a fun scene for public RP for a while but since I quit all I hear is how toxic it has become with people shaming each other on Tumblr and drama with long time players caught up in meaningless scandals. If you like ERP and know how to ignore spiteful bitter autists, you should try your luck, alternatively try your luck with the CORP community, I never bothered to.This game has so much potential! Making freeform builds is a blast, it's a simple system but it can really be mastered to make some fun and unique play styles; making characters is very easy to get into and I never once regretted buying costume parts with my subscription stipend).But it's all wasted by a cancerous publisher, an incompetetant developer and a tiny community largely populated by the worst types of person an MMO could attract. Play through what content already exists (And some of it IS decent, the end game zone, Vibora is one of my favourites in any game, actually), Mess around with some friends, play for a while, but don't spend cash unless you really have it to spare, this isn't a game to invest in and it's not a publisher or developer to support.I really hate long reviews on Steam but not enough people are telling it like it is with this game.

ber 26, 2011
												So far the variety of missions and ability to side kick to match the levels of friends for missions makes it party friendly.  Low demand and the content is broadly available whether subscribed or F2P save in a few places.  Not even main places, just nice bonuses but nothing you would miss if you didn't know about them.Costumes and customization is rather nice and varied, content is appealing and it has a Roleplay friendly environment if such interests you.  This isn't WoW where RPers would get laughed out of a city.  But a nice mix of PR/Hack n Slash, Quest and the Nemesis system is satisfying for what it currently is.Community updates are informative.  The community itself seems to be filled with friendly and helpful people.  On whole, I like it.+6yrs later Edit:Some of the content hasn't aged well, but the CC continues to be a thing of personal joy. I love the freedom to create any concept you wish, but wish the Devs gave a world that was equal to the task of housing anything from Frankenstein's' monster to Alien Robotic Entity #10 to an outright deity.CO is an RP rich potential playground for those with enough imagination to reach out and seize that, but the world needs to grow with the list of costume pieces.  It just has to. I play now for the people, not the content.  One evolves while the other still needs to.  I'd still recommend it for RPers needing a mental break but not for those seeking to grind to the end content even if there is some to be found.

												What was once a fun freeform superhero game has been destroyed by the grinding machinery that is Perfect World.Once, Champions was "alt friendly", with a wide variety of abilities that could all be used in conjunction. If you've played one of them, you know exactly what to expect from Champions.

content:
r 9, 2013
												Champions Online is one of those MMOs that comes around once in a blue moon. It is quite unique in the sense that it's one of the few superhero MMOs still remaining. WIth the fall of City of Heroes a while ago, the only other alternative is DC Universe Online, which I can't say I have an unbiased view towards. One of the game's foremost features is its costume creator, which is one of the biggest and most creative I've seen in the customization department. With this, many people have created heroes (and villains if you're into the roleplaying area) of varying shapes, sizes and colours, way more inventive than DCUO's.Champions is a most colourful game with a lot of places to visit, lots of enemies to beat the snot out of, and fun to be had with it. Unlike most MMOs, the combat is fast and intuitive. While you might get a little bored with it after a while, trying out the different Archetypes or spending a dime on becoming a Gold player for access to the Freeform layout (/don't/ waste your $50 on buying the Freeform slot if you're a free player, it can only end in tears, trust me), the game opens up a slew of new opportunities.Its most unique feature, however, is its roleplaying community. As a steadfast member of said RP community, I can safely say this is one of the biggest I've ever seen in a video game, especially for an MMO. Of course, the community is evenly split between roleplayers and non-roleplayers, and further split between good roleplayers and the scum of the earth, it is none the less one of the strongest communities I've ever seen. With the game's dwindling support ever since Cryptic, the developers, were brought by Perfect World, some members of the community will not stop fighting for it, until Champions gets the support it needs - and other Cryptic-made games, such as Star Trek Online or Neverwinter - deserve.9/10 in total - five for the gameplay, four for the community. Bravo, Champions Online. Bravo.Oh, and watch out for the demon werewolf succubus cosmic god roleplayers. You know that scum of the earth I mentioned? Yeah. Stay away from Club Caprice if you really want to keep your eyeballs.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
er 5, 2015
												Game has potential, but currently it's not worth it. It is nearly impossible to survive in this game for a few reasons. First being that there is no solid crowd control in place for Tank classes. Currently it has a feature that requires to strike an enemy to get their attention and that's not a gaurantee either. This causes squishy characters to die over and over. The game needs a solid AOE taunt power with no recharge time so that the aggro can be placed on the tank until the fight is over.  This way the squishy DPS guys can do what they are designed to--deal damage. Same goes for support characters. In a room full of bad guys, the tank needs to be able to pull aggro off of his teammates and onto him at any given time during combat--currently there is nothing solid like this in the game. Second, to make things even more difficult, you need to pay for healing patches. So not only it's difficult to survive, but also you have to pay in order to have healing patches. You can hardly call someone a hero when they nearly die killing two or three non-elite bad guys.Bottom line, if you play this game, be prepared to spend more time dying than actually playing.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
er 29, 2015
												Many years after Champions Online was released and I am now going to write this review. First off, I was a player of City of Heroes before this, so Ihave a pretty good idea of what games to hold this game's standards to. I have at least 4 max-level characters and over 1000+ hours of gametimes, so I know a few things about this game.First off, i have nothing but love for Cryptic/PWE. That being said, I'm going to offer some talking points.Why I play/played it: Champions Online is THE MOST customizable superhero MMORPG available, hands-down. THE MOST. That means  even over DC Universe Online. There are literally almost a 1000+ costume parts you can build your Champion with. This can be a hindrance for some people, as sometimes the options can overwhelm them. Which brings me to my second point. You can play anything from a Drow Elf to a Vampire, to a furred neko or even a sexy robot.Freeform vs. Archetype vs. Subscription: Subscription offers way too much to be listed here, it offers things like  unlimited Freeform Character creation, chroma-colored powers that can be colored any color you choose, etc.Freeform  character slots are purchased from the store for Silver accounts. They offer the same customization as  Subscrition minus the power-coloring.Archetypes are pre-determined power-choosing paths that are based on classic heroes and villains. Your mileage may vary, some power choices horned into the archetypes are inferior to what you COULD be putting into your build with Freeform.However this game has some caveats.1. This review is wirtten in 2015. By now City of Heroes has closed down and DC Universe Online is out. DC Universe Online IS a Superhero MMORPG where you can create your own character but your options are limited as well as your costume options. Its format is different, and the way it handles travel powers is much more fluid (ever wonder why you couldn't run up walls in CO? DCUO addresses that.)2. The game has not aged well. With the release of Star Trek Online (not a superhero MMO but one of Cryptic's newer games) and DC Universe Online, Champions feels kind of clunky. The graphics, while bright and vibrant, feel inferior to DCUO and STO. The gameplay  feels that way too, mostly because of latency/syncing issues with the servers.3. People who unsubscribe may find their characters unavailable to play as Gold Account characters because they must be converted into Silver, meaning they lose their Freeform powers. Buying a Freeform Slot does not fix this, as Cryptic has not programmed the game to make the Freeform Slots retroactive, specifically to existing Gold Account characters. Imagine not being able to play the characters you want because you want to keep their powers as-is!4.  The game lacks a postgame. Some games have a semblance of a postgame (RIFT has you doing raids, DC Universe Online has you doing dungeons for gear). Alot of the post-game stuff is just non-existent.5. The character creator can be frustrating to people who don't like lots of options or are confused by them.6. The tutorial area is confusing, I've had many of my friends say. They're unsure of what to do next or where to go, even with a blue arrow telling them where to go. As of this writing, The tutorial area is hidden inside a holodeck simulation, which is now even MORE confusing story-wise.7. The characters aren't really all that noteworthy. While I could argue that a City of Heroes 2.0 would be in order,  Champions is the result of when a MMO's licensing is cut and they need a fast replacement.8. The game's humor style seems off compared to today. While I do realize they wanted to go for that cheesy retro-humor, STO and DCUO outshine its dialogue.HOWEVER. Let's bring this full circle. Some of the things I can commend Cryptic on:1. Frequent updates. Not sure if this means they're fixing stuff (one particular bug had my game crashing everytime I attacked a particular villain).2. Great settings.3. Wide range of power choices (even when restricted to one powerset).4. The ability to play my own music from Winamp/iTunes while I slam evil.5. The story was pretty decent, as limited as it was. Also this game as Easter Eggs abound.6. The Nemesis system. No other game has it. (DCUO doesn't need it, they have a Villain faction).So yes, this game has its flaws. But there's alot of good in it too, and worth giving a play for 20 levels or so to see how you like it,  if you like superhero stuff.If you're into WoW or RIFT or D&D, I would avoid it. This game isn't serious enough for your needs.

												Played it for a couple years back in the day. It's a lot more action oriented than CoH and the graphics are better in some ways. I loved it but at one point, shortly after it went F2P they made core game mechanic changes and I wasn't willing to basically have to turn around and relearn how to play 9 max level characters again after already having had to do so (though not to as great an extent) after a not as major change previous. Also the company isn't supporting it anywhere near as much anymore as they used to. Still a pretty all right game but YMMV. Also while you _can_ play as F2P, it's a lot like SWTOR in that you're pretty well hamstrung on a number of levels with no sub. Not _as_ bad as SWTOR but still pretty bad. While I would recommend the game to someone that wanted to play a superhero MMO, it would be with reservation.
