er 25, 2014
												This game is both good and bad. It's bad in the sense that missions are repetative and you feel quite aimless as you wander through the city. Canada is cool for a couple of missions and so is the bizarro world. However, it's just not as well made as City of Heroes was. The content is good. The costume creator is mediocre and so much of the content/costume/items are "purchaseable" that really should just be part of the basic game. The amount you would have to spend to access all of these things, without any idea of how they work or what you need to do to use them is astronomical. (Sure you can earn a lot of these items over time but meh) With so many other games to choose from, I find myself only coming back to play this game in its most basic of basic formats. No vehicle, no really enhanced anything. I just can't force myself to sit long enough to figure out how everything works. I really do miss City of Heroes and it's tutorials on building mods and slotting and ... well everything that this game is not.That said, it's still enjoyable but it's a pale game in comparisson with CoX. Until Valiance and CoT, this is what we have though.

content:
y 11, 2014
												Probably the best game by the late Cryptic studios now has been ruined by region locking and unbalanced f2p features. Do not bother buying it. In fact - do not buy any games bought and ruined by Perfect World.That said - there are two things that every mmo should try to emulate in future:1) You can create completely custom characters with abilities from any class. You could easily make magic based character with some perks from tanky tech based character. You can paint all of your abilities in different colors. You can change every piece of cloth, weapon or gadget.2) Each character can grab two different methods of travel - for example superspeed and flight. Or ice-path and super jump. Teleportation and flight on a piece of earth. Each type of travel has its perks and downsides, they can also be customized with different effects and colours.Everything else is pretty much standard for mmo's - grinding, questing, instancing, group events. Unfortunately developers quickly run out of ideas and predictably were forced to make it f2p.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
r 20, 2016
												Yes. 1,780 hours. Original lifetime supporter. The game had a golden era and lots of activity. Players perceived there being a lack of support from developer Cryptic Studios as they siphoned creative and development power to launch Star Trek Online. The game suffered from prolonged bug resolution and balancing issues, but benefitted from a very large and dedicated player base. There's still quite a lot to do, and from what I understand there are still supergroups in the game that organize events and contests.I want to emphasize that the community behind this game nurtured one of the most tolerant and helpful cultures I've seen.Going free-to-play and being sold to Perfect World was a really good move since the game is clearly still being supported on some level. Champions Online Servers could have easily been retired long ago. I'm super grateful that I still have the opportunity to launch the game every once in a while to check out the latest.If you didn't have an opportunity to play Champs Online or if it never happened to be on your radar, please give it a try. It's a wonderful game full of its own lore spanning back from days when the IP was only pen-and-paper with the most robust character creation available (from old and new games alike). Cheers.

content:
28, 2014
												So a couple of years ago, this was pretty much the only game I used to play for HOURS. Like literally, I would be questing and ♥♥♥♥ and just RP'ing with people, it's a complete blast.At the same time I was also customizing the crap out of my characters because there was almost LITERALLY anything I could do and it was really fun.But then I stopped because I reached a burning out point because I had enough. So I stopped but not before clocking 475+ Hours into it.Came back to it a couple of times and found it had changed because at the time I had just left, Cryptic was bought out by PWE(Perfect World Entertaintment) and they were just making changes. Found it radically different so I played it on and off and I can say I'm back into it! It's still fun!Though I am rather sad that they scrapped the Item Crafting System that was then replaced by the Vehicle Modification System, which was in my case, a good thing because I was literally drowning in Green-tier Items and I could just dissassemble it all and make something better, y'know!So far I am enjoying it all over again with new characters and I am just having a fun blast again!PROS+ MASSIVE Customization for your Hero+ Large Open Worlds+ Thriving Community+ RP Community (if you know where to look)+ Lots of Archetypes(classes) to play around with! CONS - You can buy "Become <Something>" which are basically transformations that you can use to thoroughly wreck ♥♥♥♥. Never saw a use for them, just seem like they're OP.- [Con? Your Mileage May Vary] The stock things you can customize is somewhat limited, but twenty bucks will get you a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of costume packs if you're willing to spend some cash on it. Or you can farm for "Questionite" and exchange it for ZEN.- [YMMV] It's Perfect World Entertaintment.- Freeform Characters are locked to Gold(Subscribed) Accounts, you can make one of your characters into Freeform but it's a lot of cash to spend.Overall, highly recommend this game as it's one of the first games to ever hit the F2P Category. Play it, or don't, I don't give a crap!

content:
13, 2016
												An excellent superhero MMORPG with all original content and a very active RP scene.  More powers than you can shake a stick at, and more costume parts than powers!.  Want to be a misshapen lump of radioactive sludge, and still save people's lives?  Now you can!  Want to make your own Hulk clone?  Now you can (although you can't use the name Hulk in any way)!  Champions Online is one of the longest-running superhero MMORPG's, and I personally don't see it dying anytime soon.Note: 13.2 hours on record when launched via Steam; I've played far longer than that, starting before CO was available on Steam.

ber 20, 2015
												This is a husk and its burning. I give them the 14.99 once a year duing the anniversary month for the last three years to see if anything has improved. It hasn't. The same long standing mission failing bugs exist, causing multipart multihour missions to fail 4/5ths of the way through requiring you to either restart from the beginning or not waste your time again.Constant server disconnects (unrelated to DDOS)The queue, as in all cryptic games, is broken and frequently wastes the time of everyone in them.I only give them the 14.99 for one month for the last three years because they haven't done anything but add fluff items to drive the microtransaction revenue.The latest addition of supervillains has the typical myopicity of cryptics thought process: the supervillains are spawned near the newbie area, and have AOE attacks that kill every mob the noobs would be leveling on in a three block radius, since there are normally 4-5 supervillains ganking everyone they can in the area.This is not worth the time or money to play without freeform character creation.

content:
, 2015
												My personal favourite MMO, Champions Online allows you to put yourself in the shoes of a superhero. As a new recruit to the Champions, you are tasked with defending Millenium City from evil, such as Black Talon, Menton, the city's Gangs, and Doctor Destroyer. This game allows extreme customisation of a character, even being able to edit each part of their body. There are a few free to play character archetypes, but there are some which you need to pay to use, such as the Invincible or the Master. My personal favourite archetype is a tie between the Inferno and the Marksman, both ranged classes which deal a lot of damage. Also, what do you think of when you think of superheroes in a massive city? What, invasions? Epic battles? Well, yeah, but I think of traversing said giant city, and Champions Online does not dissapoint. From Flying to Superspeed, to Burrowing and Teleportation, there are many movement abilities. In short, I can't reccomend this game enough. It's a great MMO, with great pottential. And great power. And the other great thing that Spider-Guy whines on about.P.s, I have not spent a single penny on this game, and I can say this much good stuff about it.P.p.s, I personally have not ran into any problems, besides the occasional lag spike.

content:
0, 2015
												People who have read my Star Trek Online review may find it very surprising I didn't absolutely BASH the hell out of this game.  In fact, Champions Online shares none of the problems STO has, despite being made by the same company on the same engine!Champions Online has a massive amount of classes (20 or so) that each play differently.  You don't get access to this many classes though, if you're free to play, but the classes you do get are still pretty fun.  If you are a gold member player, you get the ability to create your OWN class that's a mix of the abilities from the others.  There are restrictions on what powers you can take, as well, which prevents you from taking the pwnsors abilities from each class and mashing em together in a Sooporman clone.  Combat is action based, rather than RPG style.  You have block abilities and that sort of thing.  I recommend using the RPG controls though, even though it can be clunky compared to the quick targetting of the FPS controls.Everything that follows is why I think Champions Online is better than Star Trek Online's bull.Trolls:  RP trolls in STO are annoying purely because they're so horribly out of character.  In Star Trek Online, if you decided to make a character whose main mode of defense was excessive flatuence, you'd ♥♥♥♥ most people off around you.  In Champions Online, not only is that totally normal, you'll get bloody groupies!  My three RP characters in Champions are an anime girl, rule 63 Dr Horrible (Bilie Awful is best original character 2015), and a drow shadowknight from Everquest complete with waterflasks and iron rations.  Have I ever been told "You know, that's kinda silly?"  Not even once!  Best place to trollRP purely because everyone else is anyway and the setting is loose enough to allow it.Gameplay:  Where as Star Trek Online pretends to be star trek combat but really was just sorta RPG ♥♥♥♥, Champions Online IS a super hero game.  You pick up park benches and throw them if you have high strength, you punch people in faces, you use super powers, you bring down the judgement of heaven and hell upon your enemies, and you just shoot em and disappoint the Joker.

			Views: 220,719		

			No description available. JonTron - Anti-Drug Games		

  Tiehn.Classes and alternatives to combat:  Lots of classes and variety between them.  A character with a blade needs to be fast on their feet to avoid taking too much damage, while Captain Hammered gets to punch everything in the face and not care about damage dealt to them.  You can't avoid combat, again, but that's forgivable, because unlike STO, there's no expectation for diplomacy to be a thing.Out of combat stuff: *shrug*  Same old ♥♥♥♥.  You either fight or socialize.  Par for the course on MMOs.  I hope EQ Next actually gets released and changes MMOs as much as the former SOE thought it would.Dialogue: Lacking.  Story missions are railroad and episodic.  Using powers out of combat: Kinda!  If your fartcharacter can fly (oh gawd) then you can fly while in the hub world too. Powers seem to behave in combat how I would expect them to.  Sniper rifles can OHKO (Oh Hell Killshot Once) while a pistol will take out the average mook in 3-5 shots to the chest.  It's when you get the demons of hell and the jetpack terrorists involved that your powers feel a bit weak, because they're being matched.  However, you will be power tripping a lot, since most of the gameplay missions have you taking down 5 people at once solo.Combat requires thought regarding combos, debuffs, and when to use your energy bar up.Conclusion:  Not Superman 64.7/10 would recommend.How to make better: Stop funneling money into STO and put it towards this game craptik.Please add the ability to add kryptonite fog for authentic superhero game experience.

content:
0, 2015
												People who have read my Star Trek Online review may find it very surprising I didn't absolutely BASH the hell out of this game.  In fact, Champions Online shares none of the problems STO has, despite being made by the same company on the same engine!Champions Online has a massive amount of classes (20 or so) that each play differently.  You don't get access to this many classes though, if you're free to play, but the classes you do get are still pretty fun.  If you are a gold member player, you get the ability to create your OWN class that's a mix of the abilities from the others.  There are restrictions on what powers you can take, as well, which prevents you from taking the pwnsors abilities from each class and mashing em together in a Sooporman clone.  Combat is action based, rather than RPG style.  You have block abilities and that sort of thing.  I recommend using the RPG controls though, even though it can be clunky compared to the quick targetting of the FPS controls.Everything that follows is why I think Champions Online is better than Star Trek Online's bull.Trolls:  RP trolls in STO are annoying purely because they're so horribly out of character.  In Star Trek Online, if you decided to make a character whose main mode of defense was excessive flatuence, you'd ♥♥♥♥ most people off around you.  In Champions Online, not only is that totally normal, you'll get bloody groupies!  My three RP characters in Champions are an anime girl, rule 63 Dr Horrible (Bilie Awful is best original character 2015), and a drow shadowknight from Everquest complete with waterflasks and iron rations.  Have I ever been told "You know, that's kinda silly?"  Not even once!  Best place to trollRP purely because everyone else is anyway and the setting is loose enough to allow it.Gameplay:  Where as Star Trek Online pretends to be star trek combat but really was just sorta RPG ♥♥♥♥, Champions Online IS a super hero game.  You pick up park benches and throw them if you have high strength, you punch people in faces, you use super powers, you bring down the judgement of heaven and hell upon your enemies, and you just shoot em and disappoint the Joker.

content:
r 8, 2014
												Champions Online is the best Hero MMO out... for the moment. With City of Titans coming out soon it may have some compition. But for now its top of the heep.Champions Online is a great game for burning time. The character creators I a very good place to make a character to play or just to mess around in creating costumes. The story is a bit lacking. Once you complete the opening missions... the game is pretty much left up to the player to follow whatever story they have availible in the mission lines and comics series.  Through the game though... there are reminders that Dr. Destroyer, the "Main Villain" i possibly lurking somewhere in the shadows waiting to return. Sadly the litle teaser seems to be just that... a tease. Beyond some daily event and a dungeon the suggest Dr. D MIGHT POSSIBLY be out there, that is basically all you get. The game has been out for a good long while, with updates and add ons. The devs do a great job up keeping in contact with the players and there is a decent amount of content for free players. You get 2-3 free character slots ( i believe you have to play for a bit to get ther third) Every so often players are given the option to try out one of the many pay to play classes for a short time.Among the many things you can do in the game Champions has the unique option of paying to make a Freeform character. This allows you to make the character with the powers and stats you want from the ground up. I you want a kid that uses fire spell has duel pistols and a giant hammer... you got it. Sadly though the character you create will most likly be off balance unless you pick specific powers to corispond with one another so there is still a limit to your creation. On the other end though you can basically make a character that is so powerful you can all but solo the entire game. A good free form build basiacally kills the need for player interaction as you can survive battles with super villains on your own. ANd there is NO END GAME. None. Once you reach a certain level, all thee content of the game will be availible. At that point you are only leveling up to get your last level power... whcih you really don't need. I was so happy to get my sniper rifle once i got max level... and only a few short mnutes later I realized I was simply playing the game as I had about 5 levels before.Finally this game seriously lacks in team work. There is almost no need for it and in areas where there is a need for it, the game has done such a bad job of preparing the players for this you don't see player using the skills they have as is needed. Healing and tanking are very poor as tanks almost always lose aggro to healers and damage dealers. Also healers tend to get killed rather quickly as the rest of the team will usually have their hand full trying to stay alive as the healer can no longer heal them.The game is definitly fun to play, but it lacks a level of heart and soul that previous games had.

content:
13, 2015
												With the fall of City of Heroes, CO is the new king of super hero MMO's. With the rising popularity of Marvel and DC movies, and the utter lack of compitition from DC online, you'd think Cryptic would have an amazing gem on there hands, right? Well sadly the answer is WRONG, Cryptic abandoned CO, if you played this game 4 years ago, you've already seen everything this game has to offer. They add some new costume packs now and then, but the main thing they keep adding to in the game is vehicles which are a total gimmick they tacked on, soley to sepperate you from your money. It is a crying shame to see the last remaining super hero MMO with an amazing character creator, left to virtually rust.Pros+ The best character creator currently available, if you can think it, you can make it or close to it, not excluding any genre, from Sci Fi, to traditional caped crusaders, to super mutant furry horse monsters with bat wings and a devil tail.+Amusing combat. Not great by any means, but if you are a gold subscriber and make free form characters (potentially picking any power you want) you can make a very attractive and satisfying looking attack combo. While its a little stale at times, some powers really revolve around one or two skills, forcing you to use them over and over again, and they might look idiotic depending on your interests.+ Extremely mobile travel powers! One of the best things about this game, is how fast you can move, how high you can jump, how easily you can fly. Other games will feel like your character has lead boots on, this game makes you so mobile.Cons+Dev's abandoned the game. No new dungeons/issues, no new enemies, story, anything. +Buggy as hell. These can go from game crashing to mild annoyances, either way, it magnifies the lack of Dev support.+Grindy, it used to be to easy to level up, you'd que in an instanced Alert, and kill a boss, get a big XP boost, repeat repeat repeat. However they switched it around within the last year, so the much longer, annoying robberies are the ones that give XP now. This forces you to do the missions more, and that leads to another con...+Boring missions. They are really dull, the story is so laughably neglected, they rip off of movies. Not super hero movies, sci fi movies. The villains motivations are so typical, and the quests never give you a reason to care about what your doing.+Cash shop is very price gouging. No option to unlock Free Form classes so you have to sub to play as those (Mixing power sets to make amazing combos and freedom) costume sets that they sell are really... limiting. They feel like they fit one look and one look only, opposed to CoH, which is odd since CO actually has an option to match textures.

content:
5, 2015
												(I would have said "Maybe" recommend it but that is not an option.)Champions Online has fantastic customization but some huge issues with things on the gameplay side.You can make any superhero you could ever imagine (almost ofc) if you buy a subscription and build a "Free-form" character. You can make them look anyway you want, you can give them any powers you want, you can make them fly or web-swing through the city to get around, or drive a jet, anything you want! It's incredibly satisfying to finish customizing your character and then romp around beating up bad guys. The game believes in freedom! :) You can play for free but you'll have less freedom and can't choose your powers other than preset learnsets.However beating up the bad guys just isn't that fun. I only lasted about two weeks into my subscription before I was 100% done. It's very repetitive. The fastest way to level up was to join a queue and beat a dungeon with four other players. This makes you never want to leave the main hub and makes the entire world seem small and pointless. The dungeons themselves are fun at first but they offer no strategy! Every boss is just "tank and spank" aside from two or three that require you to block with the shift key and a few summon adds you need to kill. There's only around five or six dungeons as well with randomly selected bosses (that are all mostly the same as I said) so you'll get tired of the same areas over and over and over. Even if you do go out and quest instead of do the instances/dungeons it doesn't get much more fun from there. It's just killing 10-20 things every quest. There aren't even collection quests generally, and even when there are, you still need to kill the mobs guarding the stuff you need to collect. There are even micro dungeons where you have to run in and find an object at the end of it, and those require you to clear out every single mob in the entire area to complete it. You cannot avoid grinding/killing mobs at all.The game believing in freedom comes at a price. The reason the dungeon/instance bosses are so simplistic is because there's no guarantee anyone will be playing a tank or a healer. They have to make sure every mechanic can be dealt with even by the squishiest DPS characters, or if your party is just five healers. It has to make sure any party can beat any boss, which sacrifices the ability to create good boss fight designs.Also the end game, when you finally hit the level cap? What do you earn? A cool new raid only accessible by high level players? Nope. A new PvP map? Nope. You just unlock more quests that give you tokens to buy better armor that you don't ever need to wear because you're already strong enough to beat any quest with ease.So do I recommend it? It's hard to say. The characters I created were conceptually really cool! I had a blast making their costumes, designing their power-sets, AND you even get to create your own bad guy! You choose their powers, their outfit, their henchmen, everything, and they show up in a particular instance/dungeon where your party of five players has to fight all five of your personally created rivals. It's really cool seeing what every one created! However all of this customization is not enough to hold the game up on its own. IF you have the money to spare and you've always wanted to create your own superhero I'd say spend 15 dollars, then shut off your subscription after the payment goes through and have fun until you get bored. The character creation is awesome but I just wish the game made you want to keep playing your character! If you're looking for a replacement for WoW/GW2 or something just don't bother. It's not nearly as compelling as the top MMOs.TL;DR: Character creation is awesome. With a subscription you can give yourself any appearance, powers, hideout and arch-nemesis you can imagine. However the game itself isn't that fun and you spend every single level, even at the level cap, grinding tank and spank enemies. Only play it if you really just want to create a superhero, not for gameplay reasons.

content:
8, 2015
												Its crazy fun selecting what your character looks like. In fact, thats where my first 3 hours game time is spent! But instantly when you join the game, the graphics change to something not quite as good looking, but it is easily over looked.It seems all starting characters are about as equally tough in comparison to each other. The tank doesn't seem anymore of a tank than a ranged character seems ranged. I feel like the game is supposed to take classes into account when you reach level 10. But why not let us play starting from level 10 then? On the same note, other games make you go to level 60, but this stops at 40. So why didn't they just strip off the first 10 levels of grinding too? Just to be sure, I want you to know that I am not complaining there aren't a million levels to grind. My complaint is that if they had the foresight to remove the last 20 level grind, why didn't they also remove the first 10 level grind too?The worst part, is that it seems that your powers and skills are no different from anyone else playing the same class. Your personal touch is left to how your character looks. Your character's uniqueness stops once you choose your class. Basically setting your character in stone once you leave character creation.UPDATE:So, I changed my mind. I like this game a lot.After you get through the tutorial level, you are about level 5. You get a free set of equipment, if you watch all 4 of the short tutorial videos. Then you get to go to train-up your levels, where you get a free travel power, a free aura, can change your suit, and get an extra suit.There are basically about 5 travel powers: Flight, speed running, super jumping, acrobatics, time-warp, and (web)swinging. Now, acrobatics is actually a very weak form of jumping with a moderate running boost, but it shouldn't count since it is a poor cross between two actual powers. (Therefore 5 not 6 basic travel powers. But it could be for someone who wants to play as a military man, Robin, or the Punisher, since it isn't much of a perk.) Almost all the rest of the super travel powers are near exact copies, but with a different animation. The super running is just as fast as the flight, but they are worded differently. The flight states it boosts you to 20 faster, then after 4 seconds boosts another 17, then after 10 seconds boosts another 17.The running states it boosts you to 100% faster, then after 4 seconds boosts another 85%, then after 10 seconds it boosts another 85%.Both, however, are the same speed.The difference between flight and rocket boots is that rocket boots start at a boost of 30, and flight has a nice animation at the point of it kicking into high speed.I noticed that the second power of my tank actually hits everyone in front of him, which is pretty cool.

content:
, 2014
												STAY AWAY. This game could have been epic and super fun. I played a lot of it when it went free, then even subscribed. Made freeform characters, loved it. Fell away from the game a while, then tried to come back, to remember why i subbed, but lo and behold, all my freeform characters were locked. My choices were 3. 1 - Re-sub (wasn't sure i wanted to again). 2 - Convert my freeform characters into an archetype (lol no). or 3 - Pay $50 for EACH CHARACTER to remain freeform without a sub. Ridiculous. Won't ever play this again. Made me want to cry seeing an account full of work locked and all i wanted to do was play them again to see if i wanted to re-sub. As i said, STAY AWAY FROM THIS TRAIN WRECK that could have been a super great mmo. Oh well. The TRULY strange thing about this game is that it is made by the same folks who made Star Trek Online, with one of the GREATEST F2P models known to gaming. I just don't understand.

content:
ber 28, 2016
												I highly suggest this game. I've played nearly every MMO out there, including DC Universe Online and City of Heroes and City of Villians, this is by far the best MMO that is created around Super Heroes. It's better than DC in many ways. 1) it's Character Creation.  2) Free Form power Creation (Allows you to pick ANY powers of any type mix n match as you level up) 3) The game has a lot to offer, I played for weeks before realizing there was a bank, an auction house and I didn't understand  the modding and upgrading gear well even in the first weeks. 4) The story behind the missions is nicely done and way way wayyyyy better than even the small stories from World of Warcraft, or DC online. There is also at times voice over during quests and missions.  5) Very long chain missions that are soloable. This is something DC and other MMO's only just recently thought about doing and Champions ONline does it better. 6) You can Free to Play the hell out of this.  7) there is an option to be a lifetime subscriber, i think it's $300 and it unlocks a ton of stuff.  I remember when DC Online had this  for a while and then they took it down!  I think more MMO's need a lifetime sub option.  Champions Online does indeed have that option! NOW FOR THE CONS.   No Villians!!!   :(   IT appears the company has put this game on hold with updates. I really hope more players subscribe and perhaps it gets the attention of the company to work hard and get back to it.Fear that the game may be shut down! This is my biggest issue. Again, support this game!

content:
, 2015
												I wanted so badly to like this game but I can't in good faith recommend a game that crashed harder than the stock market during the global financial crisis.WHAT I LIKED:The community, the players in this community are wonderful, very helpful to new players, nice and friendly.The support, although at times a little confusing they get back to you on your tickets within 24hrs (not that they could solve my issues).The customization, so much customization from your characters expression, body type, size to your outfit/costume as well as your abilities.When it worked it worked beautifully, the world was fun to explore, the missions were interesting and the range or abilities and archetypes(think classes) was great.you can enjoy this game without subscribing and many of the subscription items can be obtained through in game credits though you will need to put time in to get them(grind).WHAT I DIDN'T LIKE:Constant and random crashes, crashes for days, crashes like it was an alpha game. It crashed on start up, it crashed on character creation, it crashed in missions, it crashed in alerts(which are queued group missions) it just wouldn't stop crashing no matter how many times I verified it or re-installed it, it was one of the most crash heavy games I've ever played.FINAL THOUGHTS:If this game didn't crash so badly all the time I would re-install and subscribe today but it's just not worth it for me personally. I've played other online games like Starwars online, eve online and even world of warcraft and I never had any problems with those games in the way I had stability problems with this one. It's a fantastic game but it's just to bloody unstable!

content:
er 25, 2016
Champions Online (CO) is my first MMO game and I've played it since 2011 (with breaks every now and then) before I got myself a Steam-account some years later.I used to play it a lot before the On Alert update: I loved the old tutorial mission where I got a chance to fight side by side with the original Champions. I enjoyed the story archs, the Hero Games PvP (where lots of players joined the different games) and I really liked the crafting system.CO changed (a lot) after the update - some people say to the worse, others aren't too affected by it. The Adventure Packs which used to be Premium missions are now free, there are new missions and new features to the Millennium City map while some of the old ones are removed. I miss the Hero Games PvP-duels which are quite abandoned today since players more or less play the co-op Alert-missions instead. But in the end, it's the same game with the same Champions as before.Maybe I'm old-fashioned because I miss the old game before the update. But I still love it. While I don't have much time today compared with 5 years ago, I think CO is one of those games which have aged well (despite its cons).I hope that I may continue to play the game in five more years (at least) from today. It's one of the best superhero MMO where you can create your own superhero/superheroine and play as them with a keyboard.

content:
, 2014
												The second Craptic title, Champions Online plays like a temper tantrum by the COO of Craptic, Jack Emmert. A blatant copy of the company's first(and only good) title, Champions Online is the start of Craptic's butchering of my childhood favorites. The ONE good thing about it is the character creation. So rich and vibrant, it literally carries this game, for nothing else about CO is vaguely entertaining. The voice acting is cheesy and bad, the art style is straight out of an amateur's portfolio, missions are badly written and executed...you would think that this game is the company's first attempt, instead of its second. Craptic's other two titles occupy spots on Steam's top 100 list fairly consistently...but this one never shows up there, and for good reason. It's tripe.

content:
er 27, 2011
												If you have ever wanted to create a super hero, then CO is the game for you.  With thousands of costume pieces and powersets, this games costume creator is one of the deepest I have ever seen.  Sometimes I find myself just logging on and spending hours playing around creating unique new toons, or simply just fly around and oogling other players creations.Worth noting too, CO does not limit your gameplay, or force you to buy game essential items like map packs; one use keys to instances; rental mounts and so forth.  Instead its cash shop offers mainly cosmetic items & costume pieces, which serves to enhance your storytelling and immersion experience, but do not actually affect gameplay in any major way.  I find it refreshing to find a game where the gameplay contents are free, with regular updates, monthly events and a thriving community, a F2P game where paid contents are never neccessary, but are always welcome.

content:
ber 19, 2015
												     Never did like the graphics, being forced to turn off the default big-blocky-outline effect that never should have been there in the first place.   That generally works for your character, but then you look a bit out of place when the rest of the world and half the other characters still have the outline.  Actually, your character never really looks like it actually fits in the world graphically.     The costume designer is alright, though the asymmetrical options are lacking greatly and the overall options aren't really spectacular.  The real problem is there's no significant choices in the non-costume parts of the character.   You look remarkable similar to a large portion of the rest of the world no matter what you do.  And the cro-magnon stances that seems to be default for the male characters are as bad as the 'let me shove my chest at you' poses for the females.     The plotlines seem pulled right out of a bad Hero System chapter of a Dragon Magazine wanna-be that never sold.  And despite what the box and some dev comments say, you never really feel like you've changed anything.  The world is the same, the missions are the same, and everyone does the same things.Really the only bright spot in the game are the freeform characters.  That's not too bad and a few other games could learn something from it.  But an entire game really can't live on that alone.I so desperately miss City of Heroes.   This game simply can't fill the role, and doesn't seem like it tried despite being a Cryptic game.  You'd think they'd have a clue.

content:
4, 2015
												The game is well made and a lot of fun, but there are MANY things that make me dislike it, which is sad as it's being done by Cryptic Studios after the fall of City of Heroes. I was a player on those servers and I felt betrayed by NCSoft and I once tried this game, but it wasn't the same and now coming back to it...it's still not the same.My major gripes with the game are as follows:- Story Arcs are un-interesting and I feel no deph when playing them. The begining was interesting where you fight a simulated past where Aliens invaded and the heroes fought them off, but back in the city none of the other storys hit a cord with me at all. Fighting the purple gang can get very boring as they are simple mafia thug rip-offs like The Family from CoH.- VERY limited power uses till later levels. When you start you end up with 3 powers you use over and over which works well when playing with a controller, however it means you're very limited in your abilities as you use weak attacks to build up stamina for better, bigger attacks, but you are still limited to only a few attacks.- UI is pretty ugly IMO. The chatwindow is quite small and I often find people DON'T seem to use it. One irritating thing is when pressing F12 for a screen shot you highlight all the UIs to stretch and alter if you wish so you atleast have a option to modify it somehow.- The paywall is disgusting. Where as with City of Heroes you can combine all kinds of powers to make your own hero, in this one if you go free you get a group of Archetypes to choose from (most locked away behind a paywall as well), but if you want to mix and match to make your own unique hero you either subscribe or buy a freeform slot which costs as much as a brand new game! Not only that, but the freeform only gives you access to the powers you have already unlocked so if you have not unlocked any other archetypes then that's even MORE money to go though.Pros:- I enjoy the animation style. It's a lot of fun at times and the travel powers work quite well too and you get them earlier on than CoH which helps alot when going around the city.- Costume customisation is one of the few things they did right that they took from City of Heroes and is almostly limitless in it's customisation. Plus, if you unlock things like capes and so on, you can use on a new character which I like that they did this as a global unlock.It's a ok game and if you want to play a super hero MMO, you could do worse. It doesn't fall into the trap of DC Online where you are more imitating a famous super hero than actually becoming one yourself. If you're like me and really miss CoH then I can't recognise this as it will only scratch the barest of that itch as the restrictions and uninteresting storylines will get you bummed out. I'd instead suggest you wait for City of Titans or many other creations that are on their way.Here is the titan's website for those who might be interested: http://www.cohtitan.com/forum/index.php

, 2014
												Could be a lot of fun, the 15 a month asking price is ludicrous and the company that owns the IP now (Cryptic) is no better than the previous one (Funcom) when it comes to execution and customer service... Which is to say that they suck and don't seem to have any real interest in doing anything with the game but milking happenstance gamers. As with most of these F2P models the game is far more expensive than a AAA title if you want full functionality which I think it just a dishonest business practice used by so many of these guys. The character creater is the strongest point in the entire game, it's absolutely amazing what you can do, even with the dated graphics. I suggest anyone who is into paper doll stuff give at least that aspect a go, but don't be fooled, it's not an f2p lv 1-40 and you're nice enough to pay them for a sub (which I did) you won't be able to use any of those characters again without an active gold sub.

r 2, 2015
												Just.. not worth it any more, i was one of the first of thousands to go gun ho over this game but as many of the reviewer's stated its.. just not worth it any more you get in, you make your character, right away the difference is obviousyou are given i believe 3 difference classes or ( power sets) not realy even that honestly its just a class that some developer descided you'd like, you pick one you customize your appearance, 2nd problem most of the good attire and customizations require micro transaction a 10.00 spend for very little so you picked your pyro class, your made some carbon copy hot head, now its time to play, wich you now get to enjoy the tutorial the only part of this game that sadly even has a descent storyline any more for free, it hooks you in you run through the city destroying insectoids and now welcome to the game, do the first 8 quests then que up for alerts until your 30, all the while having pre picked skills inserted into your character. that is your Free to play expierence in a nutshell unless...you descide to buy a freeform char token for 50.00 or subscribe for the monthly subscription and oh wait look at all the new things you can do the freedom! the customizations! you try that combo, mixing and matching powers to your hearts content, trying out all the costumes you had your eye on, your character looks and feels awsome finally its time to save the world of champions online right?... wrong do the tutorial once more, que up for 8 quests, hit lvl 5 or 15 wichever, then que up for alerts once more, sure the ability to pick and choose what you want because now you pay for the game is fun.. but ultimately even that 15 a month does not give you everything so you buy this little flight power.. or that little custome travel power... maybe that one extra costume.. or exansion before you know it you've spent over 50.00 your first month and you have nothing to show for it..whats sad is ive always dreamed of descent superhero games.. i love the idea of it.. and anybody who mentions DC universe... leave just go now,.. there is just no good hero games any more and champions realy could of been it had soo much potential in the old days but like most of the devs of game, the moment a big shot company offers money to buy it out, the creators could not wait to take the money and grease themselves up like some overzealous pig races, and so like everything else Perfect World Entertainment purchases, it becomes microtranactions and prostitutionbased game play so please if anybody descides to play this.. read the reviews the ones with the thumbs down are not lieing, this game realy is a horrid piece of trash that could of been great.. but fell far.. very far.

content:
er 31, 2013
												This can be a fun game but its too simple.  While I do very much like the charector customization options(they are almost endless), I consider the game play to be too basic.  It seems to be made for kids/people with ADHD because none of the instances last more than a few minutes lol! I wouldnt recomend this to hard core gamers at all.  Its much better for younger gamers in my opinion(Yup, Im gonna get grief over that statement lol).  Anyway, I dont know whether to give this a thumbs up or thumbs down.  I think it depends upon your "maturity" as a gamer(is "mature gamer" an oxymoron?).Update almost 3yrs later; Tried to go back in and play the game again.  Nothing has changed.  Game is essentially dead, player wise(at least compared to what it was when I first posted my review).  It doesnt even appear as if much has been done to update the game or make it more dynamic.  Same exact quests, same exact everything.  The only major thing that seems to have been done to the game in three years is that options were REMOVED, not added.  Seems that I had many more choices of what kind of charector to play 3 years ago.  Now, most charector types have just one or two options available out of 6 or 8.  If you want any of the ones that arent offered, you have to pay for them.  There are still quite a few ways to customize the way that your charector looks but if you want to make any changes later-again, you have to pay for that.  Not a horrible game but just not interesting or involved enough for my tastes.  I still believe its a game that works better for a younger crowd.

content:
ber 19, 2016
												I used to play City of Heroes (CoH) on and off.  When Champions Online (CO) came out, I tried it, found it to be derivative of CoH, and the content seemed a bit too thin by comparison; CoH had been around for years, and the environment was absolutely immense and varied.  I suppose I didn't give CO a fair shake, as I only played it for a little over a week.  In a recent fit of nostalgia, I reinstalled this game, and found it to be quite enjoyable, though.  It's not the best MMO out there, but it is far better than DC Universe Online (it is painfully obvious that DCUO was written as a console game, but that's another review for another time).I'd give Champions Online a solid 7.5 / 10.  It is not the best MMO, but it is currently the best superhero MMO available.One caveat, though: be prepared to pay a subscription fee.  The game is very stripped down for free-to-play players, and it is prohibitively expensive to purchase the content one piece at a time.  A subscription is your best option.

Mobs dealing big dmg, and you can die in tutorial. But when u pick a not free archytype. There is no problem to do anything. They are literally just OP . Customization is for free player like none existent. But thats ok, no problem with that. Sidekicks, mean your "NPC PLAYER friend only for real money. No problem. Travel power, for real money. You have 2 and you need to buy another two for 1400 ! This game is just money grinder. Just a big money grinder. I still love this game. ITS SO AWESOME ! content:
, 2016
												I have played every major superhero offering in the MMO category. I try to be a fan since this is my favorite genre. But sometimes, it's just not meant to be.CO is based off of the pen-and-paper tabletop RPG of the same name. However, it's not translating well in more than a few areas. Don't let my log time fool you. I'm played way more than that as in months.The character creation is not the worse. It limits you as a FTP player in terms of the classes that you can choose but the customization is not too bad. From here, it simply creeps downhill.The content is the worst. It's cliched, trying-to-be-funny-but-isn't storylines that have absolutely no depth whatsoever. The limitations in terms of leveling is decidedly pay to play even WITH a subscription. There doesn't seem to be a whole lot of love going on befind the scenes and the graphics are horrid in my estimation. If you are a fan of the superhero genre like I am, you can skip  this wholesale.

er 22, 2014
												I was a HUGE promoter of this game when it began. I loved it. Fast paced combat, amazing character creator, cool cartoon graphics, and best of all the ability to pick and choose whatever powers you wanted.Got a lifetime subscription from day one. And, I have to say, I really enjoyed it for a long time.There were some kinks. Some systems didn't seem finished yet. I figured let it stick around for five years or so and it would just get better and better. For a while there, it was getting better. They abandoned some earlier things and added some new broken things, but they were putting out more costumes and powers and even more mission content.Then it all changed and started going to pot. Then Perfect World bought it and lockboxes galore, and now all the good stuff is held away. Playing the free version is terrible. This game had a lot of potential, but now it's all gone poof.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 15
												TL;DR: Definitely try it if you only want to Role-Play.===This game is at its best for role playing purposes.It's literally the only reason why I keep coming back to play it (occasionally). When I do, I just role play my characters with their respective story(ies). It's also fun to just click on random players around to check out their BIO (if they happen to have one of course, because not everyone plays this game for RP'ing). I've read some VERY creative stories for all types of characters. Some stories are so complex that the creator has a full Wiki-styled web page dedicated to detailing their characters. However, he in-game BIO has a character limit and you can't come up with more than about three long paragraphs of text until you hit the limit, and the formatting to create Bold or Colour text and so on also counts towards the characters limit count. So if you want to make a very fancy and elaborate BIO you'll hit the limit very fast at the cost of losing potential space to add details about your character's story.What's particularly great about this game's world is that - outside of its base / canon lore - you're still very much free at creating almost literally EVERY types of heroes and/or villains that you can imagine. You want to create a Cyborg, Robot, Demon, Angel, generic Metahuman with super strength, miniature butterfly guy who has the power of teleportation, a Vampire or an Alien with bunny ears and a guitar for accessory... just imagine it and you can most likely do it. The sheer number of possible characters from this game's creation system is - quite simply put - out of this world. There are NO other games currently available (MMOs or not) that can come remotely close to that kind of customization (INCLUDING your character's own BIO / back story if you want to invent one too outside of just making his appearance unique).Not to mention that there's the (in)famous Club Caprice, 'THE' place for Role-Players to meet. And if you're into more... shall I say "complex" RP'ing and need more privacy you can also just invite your partner to your own place. Indeed, there's Hideouts and you can invite players inside, be it a Penthouse or a Moon base, there's quite a good selection (some are smaller than others though).I'm just speaking about the Role-Playing aspect here, because I myself have pretty much ignored the ACTUAL "game" behind the curtain (to me, the real game in Champions Online IS the role-play, so everything else it offers IS behind the curtain) over the years. I've literally just leveled up ONE character to Level 35 and stopped there for the past two years now (max Level is 40). My other characters are Levels 25 and below. I just literally buy Hideouts, costumes and costume packs, costume Slots for my best characters, character Auras and so on, mostly due to Role-Play.So, coming from a (rather humble) role-player, I absolutely recommend this game. However, if what you're looking for is a good actual MMORPG and you cannot possibly care and won't even approach its RP capabilities then I do NOT recommend this. Instead I'd go for something else like Elder Scrolls Online, Black Desert or even Blade & Soul.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
y 15
												The same programmers made City of Heroes and City of VIllains which was an excellent game, but is no longer available.  City of Heroes was the best superhero game ever, the AoE powers and gameplay was great for tank to herd and blasters to nuke.Champions Online was an attempt to make City of Heroes more of an action game, having to click each time you attack in a frantic/actionfilled manner, as opposed to City of Heroes where timing the powerset attacks was more the gameplay style.  In other words, Champions Online has more button pushing an less thinking.Champions Online is more of a fighting game than City of Heroes which was a action strategy role playing game.Too bad City of Heroes no longer exists.A game more similar to City of Heroes is DC Universe Online.I would play DC Universe instead, which is also free to play.Even with all that said, I would recommend this game to others if they like fast action button clicking, superhero genre, and free to play.

And if you're into more... shall I say "complex" RP'ing and need more privacy you can also just invite your partner to your own place. Indeed, there's Hideouts and you can invite players inside, be it a Penthouse or a Moon base, there's quite a good selection (some are smaller than others though).I'm just speaking about the Role-Playing aspect here, because I myself have pretty much ignored the ACTUAL "game" behind the curtain (to me, the real game in Champions Online IS the role-play, so everything else it offers IS behind the curtain) over the years. I've literally just leveled up ONE character to Level 35 and stopped there for the past two years now (max Level is 40). My other characters are Levels 25 and below. I just literally buy Hideouts, costumes and costume packs, costume Slots for my best characters, character Auras and so on, mostly due to Role-Play.So, coming from a (rather humble) role-player, I absolutely recommend this game. However, if what you're looking for is a good actual MMORPG and you cannot possibly care and won't even approach its RP capabilities then I do NOT recommend this. Instead I'd go for something else like Elder Scrolls Online, Black Desert or even Blade & Soul.

City of Heroes was the best superhero game ever, the AoE powers and gameplay was great for tank to herd and blasters to nuke.Champions Online was an attempt to make City of Heroes more of an action game, having to click each time you attack in a frantic/actionfilled manner, as opposed to City of Heroes where timing the powerset attacks was more the gameplay style.  In other words, Champions Online has more button pushing an less thinking.Champions Online is more of a fighting game than City of Heroes which was a action strategy role playing game.Too bad City of Heroes no longer exists.A game more similar to City of Heroes is DC Universe Online.I would play DC Universe instead, which is also free to play.Even with all that said, I would recommend this game to others if they like fast action button clicking, superhero genre, and free to play.

content:
, 2014
												This game is in every way shape and form a step back from a game that already came out 10 years ago - City of Heroes. Why they decided to continue Champions Online and completely shut down CoH completely baffles me, I guess the microtransaction model was already in place for Champions so it seemed more profitable. Regardless, I've lost all respect for the company for selling out like that.Basically the game is your standard free to play microtransaction bullcrap that plagues the market today. Some of the ploys they use to get money are laughable. For instance, when you build your first character, there will be items included in things such as a Halloween pack and a dryad pack that allow you to select them without having an indicator by their name that you have to purchase them (even though there are other items that are selectable such as Ancient Armor cosmetics, which clearly state they must be purchased) - so basically it tricks you into thinking those items are selectable and available for your character, then once you are done finishing your character it pops up a dialogue saying you have items that must be purchased otherwise they will not show in game, because it turns out (shock) that you have to pay for things like the halloween pack and dryad pack... what an absolutely scummy way of trying to trick users into paying. On top of that the character creation is just a huge step down from CoH, half the items when you put in certain combos and certain scalings (common ones I might add) have awful looking graphical glitches like a shoulder pad having your shoulder pop right through it and show visibly from the outside. On top of that, when you get into the actual game, it's cell shaded (even though the character creation screen WAS NOT) and you basically get a character that doesn't even look like what you created.In general the cel shaded graphics look like ♥♥♥, and it is also a huge step backward from the already gorgeous game with 10 year old graphics - CoH.There are also less than half the choices for unique and cool skill sets that CoH had, which is ridiculous. The only melee classes are weapon classes, so forget the cool things such as claws and spikes.Combat is awful, and leveling up is dumbed down, basically they made this game for people that don't want to worry about building a character rpg style, and just want to play some mindless arcade-like game.The game has half the character and passion the original game had, it's really sad to see this is what is left of the once glorious CoH.If you want to play a free-to-play mmo with superheros (or any mmo with superheros for that matter) the DC Online game is the only way to go. It's not perfect, but it's better in every way shape and form than this lackluster game "Champions Online" is.Don't waste your time with this game, it's trash.

content:
er 26, 2013
												Sit on a cactus. You feel that? Believe it or not what you just did is more fun (and less painful) than playing Champions Online.After my beloved City of Heroes got shut down I decided to try this thing. Played it for a solid month and got bored before that month was up. It has the most tedious combat of any MMO I have ever played. All attacks auto hit, no real strategy to speak of. Just stand and button mash. In CoH you could strategize by enhancing powers with damage, accuracy, range etc. There was the chance attacks would miss. You had to be careful what to use and when. Here it's just pew, pew, pew mindlessly.I wanted a telekinetic character. It's bloody annoying to throw one single object. Click the object, click to lift, click on target, click to throw! Click, click, click, click for one attack that won't even one shot an even level trash mob! The mechanics of this game are boring and a chore.Most content is stuck behind the pay wall. Problem is that unlike DC Universe Online (where a sub can be worth it) you'd just be paying for a boring game rather than playing a boring game for free. I've no idea what the Marvel MMO is like but if you want to be a hero play DC Universe Online or simply mourn COX's demise.The only one tiny good thing about this game is the sheer choice of travel powers. Not worth it. Sod the cactus, stick a fork in your eye. Still less painful than Champions Online.

												Champions Online: Free for All is the standard base-building, tower defense/offense game that you've seen about a hundred times before, but this time it's got a thin veneer of the CoD franchise sprayed on top. The "Champions" bit comes from the fact that some of the leading characters of the previous games in the franchise will show up to help boost your forces. The usual leveling system has been implemented, complete with in-app purchases to make it go faster, all the way up to $99.99 (almost double the cost of the latest console game). Way to be subtle, fellas.

content:
y 12
												Wow, there's some harsh critisizm hanging around from people who didn't even give the game the time of day.I've played a great many MMOs in my time and Champions is the only one I always come back to. Nothing beats the feeling of just swinging/running/flying through the city beating up bad guys and saving civillians.I orginally got into this came when I was looking for a replacement to fill the Freedom Force shaped hole in my heart and I've been playing on and off ever since.  I even survived the buyout from PWE.  The game has gone through a lot of changes and not all of them are positive, but there's still plenty of reasons to play.Some good points:>Walking through the door, you have access to create your hero's every physical aspect.  Rather than choosing between one of 8 premade faces and skin tones, you have hundreds of options available to you (And yes you have more if you choose to buy them).  On top of that you have thirty odd sliders to change the size, shape, and detail of every choice you've made.>Also walking through the door, your hero can already fly.  Or have super speed, or teleport.  You don't have to wait until you hit X level before you can get a mount.> You feel like a super hero.  You can fly, when you punch guys you can send them flying, You can have lazer eyes or breathe ice. You can be indestructable or set yourself on fire.>You can make just about any hero you can dream up. They have some set archatypes that function as pre-built 'classes' that give you a few choices but have a solid theme or power set, but the real joy is in going freeform and making your very own hero drawing from any power set you want.  You want to make a Speedster that weilds a sword and uses his friction to throw fire? Done. Do you want to be a robot ninja with a shotgun? Done. Psychic Dinosaur from Outer Space? Got you covered. Even the sky isn't the limit.>The story is very comic booky and has a self-aware sense of humor.>They are frequently releasing new comic book stories, events, costume parts, and even power sets.>The player base is friendly and supportive.  More so than any other online game I've played.  Other players are actually happy to help you or tell you how to get the cool thing they have or to talk characters.A few Bad things:>Yes, the game is F2P.  That means you 'can' play without giving them money.  No, you will not have access to all the bits and bobs and cool things as some of the other players do. However,  If you are willing to devote time to the game, you can in fact get everything that paying players can by selling in-game currencies for real money.>The graphics are a little behind what would be considered the norm at the moment. This being said, it dose make it easier to run on older computers.>The amount of front-loaded personalization can seem intimadating when starting out.  Just jump in, you'll figure it out.  And dont' be afraid to make a mess.In closing, if you don't like the Super-Hero genre, this game probably isn't for you. If makeing choices or customizing your own character sounds like too much work for you, you'd probably be happier elsewhere.  But if you do love Comic Books and are the creative sort, and spending hours on end designing, redesigning, and playing your very own superheroes sounds like your kind of a fun time, this could be one of the best games you'll ever buy... or not-buy.

												Well, this is just sad. I had truly hoped that this game would live on and grow bigger. I stopped playing a while back when the game offered so much. I'm almost baffled by the fact that the devs have not only restricted almost 100% of new content to paying customers, but they took STUFF THAT WAS ALREADY FREE and added a price tag on it. There is no justification for that. Once upon a time, this game offered free-to-play users a perfect alternative for those looking for a superhero game. Now, it doesn't offer anything above a taste, if even that.I cannot stress this enough: Don't play this game. If not for the fact that it's a waste of your time now, then for the principle. They took a perfectly fine game. A game that I was surprised at for being so full and colorful. And now it's dull. These devs ruined something good, and they don't deserve our time. 0/10 all the way.

												Now. Before I start I would like to state that even though I have spent 15.5 hours on this game, I know how fun it is to play since I got to level 17 within 10 hours (First character leveling problems since I had no idea what to do)Anyway after deleting my first character which was a Soldier (I hate that class now) My friend convinced me to make a new character with her. So I did. I would recommend this game for people who like game like DC Universe online as I feel it has the same feeling as it.Pros-Good CustomizationGood CombatFun LevelsFun BossesFun Character DesiginsBetter with FriendsGood musicCons-Some Classes feel underpowered while some feel overpoweredMay be hard going soloNot being able to run up the side of buildings (How is it possible to get to the tops of roofs with enemies on when there is no roof door around. The only way I found is jumping on the ledges that hand out)So overall I recommend this game for people who like Superheroes and MMORPGS

content:
er 7, 2016
												Though I quickly became bored of Champions Online, I recall it having very in-depth visual customization, as well as character setup. In the style of the City of Heroes games, you could mix and match powers to create your ideal superhero. It also had a fairly appealing, in-your-face comic book style look to it, with bright colors and heavy cel-shading outlines. It's probably still worth playing if you'd like an alternative to the stale fantasy MMOs.

content:
er 25, 2013
												I played this for several hours to to earn the Christmas achievement back in 2011, when Valve was rewarding us with coal for them. Had it not been for that I would not have stayed with the game nearly so long. It's a very generic game, not particularly good looking or with much character to speak of, and the gameplay is entirely forgettable. WoW has the sheer size of its player base and content developed over the years, TERA has an enjoyable combat system, but this game has nothing to hold your attention unless you really, really love superheroes (and not even any actual comic book ones).

4, 2014
												The game itself is decent, admittedly it was a step back from City of Heroes/VIllains (becoming something closer to a generic MMO). The gameplay itself isn't bad, but the F2P setup is downright appalling. You lose out on the customization if you decide not to pay the monthly fee (the game isn't good enough to warrant the fee). Instead, I recommend DCUO, while not stellar, it did a much better job of allowing you to make the character you wanted.

content:
y 9, 2014
												Not to be underestimated.Ever since the fall of, "City of Heroes/Villians" I've been wandering the internet, looking for a game that can quench my thirst for.. Justice! Champions Online does that very well, you have the choise of many possible powers from; Dual Gunning/Katana to Mental Telepathy/Power Suit, which sometimes makes me pout in frustration because there is so much to choose from. The thing that makes this game shine the most is the customization in both your look and powers if you Subscribe ($15 Month USD), buy a Lifetime Subscription ($299.99 USD), or buy a Free Form Slot ($50 USD), you are able to literally combine powers to make a super hero in your image.  For Free Users the game is still fun and customizable just a little limited, Free users choose their, "Archtype Powers" which is a set of powers that are already created from the start and have an ability layout, Free Users are also limited to costume peices but have alot to choose from the start. If you want more costume peices you can get them by; Cash Shop, Enemy Drops, Quests and Events. The game is very balanced for both Paying and Free players there is no Pay to Win at all! I've seen a lot of F2P Players whoop P2P Players super hero butts no problem. All and all I say you should really try this game, reviews help but experiencing the game cuts the cake!

content:
3, 2016
												FIrst, let me say that even though I recommended it, I wish I could give a neutral. I played the game when it was first released, when it was Pay2Play, and it was okay then. There was a feeling of more freedom in creating your characters, but I felt the questing was worse back then. And once Perfect World took over and it went Free2Play the character creation was more linear, without paying, but the questing got better, in my opinion.The game is fun, but it's not great. It has a decent amount of content, but lacks in late game from what I have heard. Haven't got that far myself.Good character creation. With the time I have in the game I'd say probably around 10 hours of it was playing with the character creator, even with me not having access to all of the costume pieces. You have to pay for most costume pieces. Or you can sub to get all from what I've been told. Never done it myself.Fun powers. The powers in the game are quite interesting and for the most part feel different from the others. However you only get 10 powers free, which is pretty alright. But that does leave the other 17 locked away. You can get them by paying for each one, getting a subscription, or using ingame currency and converting it into real money currency which takes quite some time. You can also get Freeform characters, which is a a way of mixing powers together. You want to shoot ice and breathe fire? Use Freeform. But that isn't (always) free. If I remember correctly a single Freeform character slot cost $50. You can also do a sub and Freeform becomes available. Or they will sometimes give them away for free, that's how I got mine.From what I have played the game has 3 major zones. The city, a Desert, and the Canadian Wilderness (or a frozen wasteland), and all of the areas have some fun things going on, or at least have some interesting things to look at. Now, I realize that 3 zones seems small, but the zones themselves are a decent size. In all the time I have in the game I still have not fully explored any of the zones, granted I do switch, delete, and create characters often.Overall this is my favortie Perfect World owned game, the only one I like actually. I recommend this game, but I still wish I could give a neutral.

content:
18, 2014
												This game can be a lot of fun with friends. The character creation options are very impressive. You can spend a ton of time designing a perfect hero and as you progress in the game, costume unlocks will become available to you randomly or through other means.  Along with this, the places that you can travel around are huge so if you're the kind of person that likes to travel around this is a definite plus.  With friends you can take down bosses with ease, conquer different crime organizations, and enjoy the plots your character is tied into.Without friends you can do the same, but it may not be as fun, especially with the Alert system and weekly events that take place.  Some events need good teamwork and organization to pull off, but if you don't have friends that are interested in playing or available, the community in game are more than kind enough to assist those in need.  Not only that, but the sheer amount of different appearances of heroes may spark more creativity for your character (or nemesis once you reach a certain level).The downside is that this game has a ton of costumes, devices, and most recently vehicles that will cost a pretty penny to obtain with real money. There are methods to obtain most in game, but it will require a lot of grinding for resources that is a pain.  Vehicles are probably the most annoying to try to obtain without actual cash since they reduce the time it takes to get from one end of a map to the other by at least half according to a few people, but are possibly the most difficult to get.  If you need to get to a place fast, such as a friend that is fighting a boss in the corner of the desert while you are at the south end of Canada, it will take forever to reach your friend to help without improved travel powers or a vehicle.  However, the vehicles are not required to play the game or progress your character to max level, so while it is a downside, it isn't a big one.Overall it's still a fun game to play. If you have a decent computer and like being a superhero, give it a try. If you have a friend that likes being a superhero bring them along as well. The more the merrier!

												I have played this game before, just recently got it on steam - hence the time spentThe character creation is probably the best I've ever seen in any FTP MMORPG title yet. It's so diverse and there are just so many choices to choose from, I loved it. Literally most of the time I spent in the game was character creation. On other things, it's quite an average mmorpg, typical for the genre, however quite fun. It doesnt bring anything innovative when it comes to gameplay (maybe besides throwing things - that's cool). The aspect that you can explore a rather large world is very nice, I enjoyed that a lot. Cool quests, not very repetitive - the world isnt as interactive as I'd perhaps like, but it's fine.  PROS Great character creationNice, large worldQuests arent repetetiveFun combatLarge selection of customizable classes to choose fromOpen Quests CONS You dont see your full costume straight awayHas fairly annoyijng p2w aspectsYou can't select a special power that you get from the start (I mean flying, of course I do)Gets a bit grindy at stagesOverall I give this a solid 79/100, One of the best MMOs out there today, definetly wortha try if you're into superheroes and badass looking helmets

content:
26, 2014
												For  those  missing  the  hole  left  their  heart  by  the  departure  of  City  of  Heroes,  Champions  Online  can  help  fill  in  the  gap....a  little  bit.  In  many  ways,  the  game  has  a  much  different  feel  than  the  average  MMO,  such  as  a  need  to  be  more  precise  in  targetting.  While  ranged  characters  retain  auto-aim,  melee  is  more  about  actually  aiming  strikes.  The  character  creator,  though  more  limited  than  City  of  Heroes,  has  a  vastly  larger  number  of  customization  options  than  the  average  MMO,  as  opposed  to  some  popular  MMOs  like  DCUO  and  SWTOR.  The  game  has  major  short  comings  however  in  that  it  is  very  relient  upon  teaming  up  with  other  players,  and  some  difficulty  spikes  can  make  the  game  a  nightmare  to  try  and  play.  It  also  is  a  very  cartoony  and  comic  book  styled  MMO,  so  don't  expect  a  serious  story.  If  you're  look  to  fart  around  with  a  better  character  creator,  you  could  certainly  do  worse  than  Champions  Online.  But  if  you  really  want  to  play,  you're  better  off  waiting  for  City  of  Heroes  to  be  re-released  as  City  of  Titans  in  2015.

content:
23, 2016
												Champions Online is one of the most enjoyable free to play MMO's you will ever pick up. If you're a fan of superheroes, or supervillains, you can trust that this will be the only game out there that lets you not only play however you want to play, but be whoever you want to be. You can create whatever kind of hero you want, from flying, cape wearing, tight laiden superheroes with slick hair and super strength, to disgusting bettle creatures with poisonous spit.Now, there are disadvantages to being free to play, but not in the sense that you think. Free to play is limited in what archetypes you can choose for your base character type, which, admittedly, is somewhat limiting in itself. However, starting the game with an archetype is most likely the best way to learn and master the game (learn how to block).Subscribers get way more than what they pay for in sheer content. But the one thing that's absolutely worth the 15$ a month is the freeform character that you can only have as a sub. Freeform lets you be what you want to be. It's totally worth it, but it's not easy to figure out right off the bat, and freeform demands a bit of game knowlege and role knowlege before you can just jump into your own custom hero with whatever powers you fancy. This game is worth your time, and in my opinion certainly worth your money. SO get it peeps!

content:
, 2016
												It's hard to give this game a recommendation, but I'm going to do so on a basis that I'll explain below.I disagree, it's not necessarily pay to WIN as it is pay to have fun as you see fit. I do think it's ridiculous I'd have to pay money to pick a character class that I do want to play (though I've found some love for The Mind and The Blade archetypes) and, yes, slightly ludicrous that I have to pay for certain aesthetics. Gameplay-wise, the game is as linear as I'd expect of any MMO. Combat is basically all keybinds and dodging area specific attacks. Things become slightly more enjoyable when you know what your class is supposed to be doing, in my opinion. That said, it winds up devolving into raids at some point, like most MMOs. I find myself having less customization than I did in City of Heroes. Still, the character creator IS top notch and you do have a lot of flexibility there, so the game deserves credit for that.Would I recommend this game purely on gameplay? No. It can get clunky, it's not the most immersive on the planet and you do have to break some paywalls if you want to play it as you'd like. The community isn't too hot either. The point I was going to make: I find myself mostly role-playing and getting into character to pass time. It does make the game more enjoyable if you have a good group to get involved with, but like I said above, the community isn't great. It's almost essential to join a super group/guild in order to find said group as most people have the social skills of a malevolent parasite, are searching for E-RP (erotic roleplay) or are too elitist to involve anyone they perceive as an outsider or new. Still, I'm biased, I did find a good group myself, so it's not completely farfetched for others to do the same. On the basis of an extensive character creator and role-play potential, I recommend this game. Beyond that, it's best to explore other alternatives. You can tell the company gave up on this game a long time ago.

y 28, 2013
												This is the MMO version of the Hero System games superhero universe "Champions". It is free to play, and in a good way. You get access to all of the zones and can level to 40 along with the subscribing customers. The only limitation is that you must play a pregenerated power set called an Archetype. However, you are still in full control of your character's appearance. Character customization in this game is incredible. There is a wide variety of costumes to choose from, and there is also a wonderfully detailed system for changing your character's physical dimensions and facial features. It really is a fun little game for a freebie, and I daresay worth the price of subscription just to have access to the Freeform character slots that let you pick and choose your powers yourself.

												_THE_ best MMORPG I have ever played so far. Great customizability, nice gameplay, funny missions, thousands of cross-references, awesome adventure packs, the list goes on.However, be warned that PvP is far from balanced, though there are some great PvP events that are loads of fun, like the zombie attack! Also, bear in mind that this is a marvel/dc superhero kind of game.But all in all, I'd always recommend giving this game a try - and if you like it, you can always upgrade to gold member to unlock fully customizable powersets, a huge buttload of new costumes and a crazy lot of other things. Don't feel like paying for a subscription? Well don't! Everything you gain by subscribing can also be purchaes in the C-store to be permanently unlocked for silver members!Shoot enemies with fire, lightning, guns, a rocket launcher or orbital bombardement, tear them apart with your waraxe or chainsaw gauntlet - in this game, everything goes. What are you waiting for, hero?
